title_narrative: NUWOSO COVID-19 Project
sector_narrative: The right to life and security
description_narrative: NUWOSO and ODOWOL consortium will implement the below activities under COVID-19 project:1. Sensitize estimated 27,272 people on COVID-19 virus    Project shall use media approach by partnering with Local FM radio station TEMBO FM for talkshow, radio spot Messages and Road drive using van with public address system and Boda-Boda talk using megaphone to educate public on COVID-19 virus prevention and case management.2. Procure and install  20 hand washing facilities in public places to promote hygiene and  prevention of  COVID-19 virus infections    Project shall procure and establish hand washing facility in public places like, markets, health facilities, water points, Boarder points, meeting places, Police office, Army barracks and disinfectors (jik) and soap to promote handwashing practices for hygiene and prevention of COVID-19 virus spread and infections.3. Procure and allocate protective gears to 70 COVID-19 virus task force teams and project staffs.    The project shall procure and allocate the protective gears including Gumboots, Gaggles, apron, disinfectors, Face Masks, Antiseptics for hand hygiene, Spray pump, Gloves to 70 COVID-19 virus task force teams and  project staffs  to prevent them from COVID-19 virus infections risk and vulnerability during conducting project activities4. Support District established referral services and networks for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response and case managementProject shall support established District COVID-19 virus referral services  and networks from community-heath facility for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response and case management through facilitation  for the operation of the District Ambulance 24/7, facilitation for health worker Incharge of referral services, Facilitation of  District officials for support supervision to  the established COVID-19 virus treatment centers in Padibe health center IV and Madiopayi health center IV for quality COVID-19 virus services delivery.5. Support  2 established COVID-19 virus  treatment centers with necessary logistics for effective and quality care and response servicesProject shall provide necessary logistics in the 2 targeted established COVID-19 virus treatment centres in Padibe health center IV and Madiopayi health centre IV for effective and quality care and response services.6. Support established District and sub-county level COVID-19 virus response coordination, communication and networking for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response services.Project shall support the District officials for support supervision and enforcement of the COVID-19 virus regulation, support monthly District and sub-county COVID-19 virus taskforce coordination meetings,  support function of the COVID-19 virus taskforce team for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response and case management.7. Conduct 2 hours Project Inception and orientation meeting.Project shall organize 2 hours inception and orientation meeting targeting District Health Officer(DHO), District Education Officer(DEO), Chief Administrative Officer (CAO), LCV, District Health Educator(DHE), District Water Officer(DWO), Incharge of Padibe H/C IV and Madiopayi Health Center  IV, District Health Inspector(DHI), Resident District Commissioner(RDC) and District Internal Security Officer (DISO) and District Police Commander(DPC) and NGOs partners, NUWOSO <(>&<)> ODOWOL Board of Directors to share the project implementation plan and their roles and responsibilities in the project implementation.8. Conduct 1Join project performance Monitoring, Evaluation and LearningProject shall conduct 1 join performance Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning with the District monitoring team including  assessing  the project achievements and best practices employed in theproject implementationin order to achieved the project desired goal and objectives
result_description_narrative: Women and Men able to:  # of people (M/F) living in poverty and injustice use their enhanced knowledge and skills to respond effectively to disasters

participating_org_narrative: NORTHERN UGANDA WIDOWS & ORPHANS SU NUWOSO

Northern Uganda Widows and Orphans Support Organization (NUUWOSO) was formed to address the challenges affecting women and childrenin Northern Ugnada in areas of Health, Poverty, Disaster and Rights Issues, NUWOSO was formed in 2005 by the Late Mother ATARO JULIAN and other 12 Women who were affected by HIV/AIDS and Northern Ugnada conflict in Agago County. NUWOSO started as community groupsin 2005 with the name Patongo Widows and Orphans Support Group (PWOSG) who came out to support themselves in order to address the impacts of HIV/AIDS and War on women and children,  later the group though of extending their memberships and services to other sub-counties and communities by registering with government and this make them to think border for the name touse for registration at district level  as CBO, them chosen to used the name #Widows and Orphans Support organization(WOSO)#, the group completed their registration with Pader District local Government  Reg. No. 014 and they  became CBO, after when Agagodistrict was coved out of Pader in 2010 by act of parliament , The group registered with Agago District Local Government in 2017 as CBO Reg. No 087. After when the groupthough of expanding their services countrywide, they started the registering the organization with Ministry of Internal Affair but during the NGO name preservation with the office of Ministry of Internal Affair the name WOSO is already existing/ being used by another organization, then the group decided to change the name to be Northern Uganda Widows and Orphans support Organization (NUWOSO) and was approved and preserved and late group applied to NGO Board for national registration in January 2019 and in July 2019 the organization got registered as NNGO with registration No:  INDR138721925NB and mandated to operate countywide with the programmes of health, Economic and livelihoods, Education, Social protection, Environmental  conservation and Disaster management2. ACHIEVEMENTSWhat have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion?2018 NUWOSO in consortium with FOKAPAWA, AVCT, and PCCO implemented WASH in Agago district in flood affected sub-counties (Patongo, Omot, Lirapalwo andAdilang), with funding from OXFAM. 750 severely affected H/H supported, 4 primary school supported, 1 institution (Prison) supported, estimated average of 7268 peopleserved (4894 Females and 2374 Males)2017/2018 NUWOSO with support from PEPFAR-Uganda 642 prisoners in Patongo Government prison served (456 Males and 2374 Females).2012-2015 with funding support from JCRC-CSF reached out to 28,456 people (17,297 Femalesand 11159 Males) with HIV/AIDS prevention, care, treatments and support services in 4 sub-counties (Patongo, Adilang, Lirapalwo and Omot) in Agago district3.    INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSEMission: What is the current purpose of the organisation?Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term?Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works?  Who are the social actors that benefit fromthe work?NUWOSO MissionNUWOSO exist to empower and build resilient women and children in Uganda through Health Services, Economic and Livelihood Support, Education Support, Social Protection, Environmental Conservation and Disaster ManagementNUWOSO Objectives1. To increase access and utilization of HIV prevention services among most at risk key population (MARPS) in Uganda.2. To increase access and utilization of HIV/AIDS care, treatment and support services among adults, adolescent and children living with HIV/AIDS in Uganda.3. To increase access and utilization of Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) Rights and services among adolescent#s girls and young women age 10-35 years in Uganda4. To empower women, OVC households and youth with sustainable economic and Livelihoods for improved  income, nutrition and food security  in Uganda5. To provide social protection services and support to women and children in Uganda6. To provide formal and non-formal education services and support to OVC/youths in Uganda.7. To promote and protect environment in Uganda.8. To sensitize community on disaster preperness and response to crisis  to save-lives and alleviate suffering of women and children in Uganda9. To improve organizational effectiveness and efficiency for a better quality servicesNUWOSOProgramme THEMATIC areas1. Health Program2. Economic <(>&<)> Livelihoods Program3. Social Protection Program4. Education Program5. Environmental Conservation Program6. Disaster Management ProgramNUWOSO Geographical areasAgago, Pader, Oyam. Omoro, Oyam, Lamwo, Amuru, Abim, Karenga, Nwoya,Social actors that benefit from the NUWOSO work# Women, Children, Youths and Men# Community members# Local leaders# Cultural and religious institutions# Community groups# Government# Private sectors# Development  partners4. STRATEGIC POSITIONINGAnalyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation?1. Private sectors (Medias, Business communities)2. Government3. Development partnersThe private sectors like media play roles ineducating public on NUWOSO services and issues affecting them, business communities support NUWOSO with good and services provisions, Government provide technical support, partnerships, resources , development partners play role in provision of support both technical,human resources, finance and logistic etcThe position of NUWOSO is unique in a sense that, NUWOSO have the shared vision  and mission with these social actors, good partnerships and coordination/ working relation , resource sharing5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart)How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of people in each position, and if they are men or women.General Assembly (GA) is asupreme governing organ of NUWOSO which comprises of 36 members (26 women and 10 Men), they meet once every year to get feedback on the organization achievements, review constitution and policies and make amendment where necessary, approve annual work plan andbudget.Board of Directors comprise of 9 members (6 women and 3 men) headed by Chairperson (Female) assisted by Vice Chairperson and they meet quarterly, they key formulate policies and implementation, oversee the management staff and organizationdevelopment, they report to the General Assembly annually.Management staff or secretariat comprise of 3 staff (2 Males and 1 Female) , they are  headed by Programme Coordinator, their roles is to ensure organization programmes day-to-day running/implementation and management, resource mobilization for organization development,  they report to Board of Directors, relevant stakeholders and Donor(s) quarterly and annually.

Development partnersThe private sectors like media play roles ineducating public on NUWOSO services and issues affecting them, business communities support NUWOSO with good and services provisions, Government provide technical support, partnerships, resources , development partners play role in provision of support both technical,human resources, finance and logistic etcThe position of NUWOSO is unique in a sense that, NUWOSO have the shared vision  and mission with these social actors, good partnerships and coordination/ working relation , resource sharing5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart)How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of people in each position, and if they are men or women.General Assembly (GA) is asupreme governing organ of NUWOSO which comprises of 36 members (26 women and 10 Men), they meet once every year to get feedback on the organization achievements, review constitution and policies and make amendment where necessary, approve annual work plan andbudget.Board of Directors comprise of 9 members (6 women and 3 men) headed by Chairperson (Female) assisted by Vice Chairperson and they meet quarterly, they key formulate policies and implementation, oversee the management staff and organizationdevelopment, they report to the General Assembly annually.Management staff or secretariat comprise of 3 staff (2 Males and 1 Female) , they are  headed by Programme Coordinator, their roles is to ensure organization programmes day-to-day running/implementation and management, resource mobilization for organization development,  they report to Board of Directors, relevant stakeholders and Donor(s) quarterly and annually.

participating_org_narrative: ACTION 4 HUMAN RIGHTS & EDUCATION I AHEDI

AHEDI- UG is an Organization formed by young university graduates in the field of law and social work in July 2008 to promote, defend and protect rights of every citizen regardless of tribe and nationality; #Justice for All#. The organization has mainstreamed itsactivities in the area of GBV/VAWG, PHA victims, Women and children in conflict with the law, Land rights, Legal and social consultancy for Local governments (on Policy and legal Issues) and other vulnerable persons, working towards improving the legal framework and awareness on human rights and fundamental freedom, land and property rights.AHEDI-UG delivers holistic and citizen friendly programs with particular emphasis on GBV/VAWG,HIV/AIDs, emergency response to humanitarian issues, land rights/property ownership, psycho-social support, legal and social consultancy that leads to  sustainable development and livelihood.AHEDI-UG works with a number of partners in the execution of its mission including political and technocrats at the districts of west Nile sub region and Uganda at large, members of parliament (MP), traditional leaders, central government representatives, other NGOs, CBOs and Faith base leaders among others.The turning point in the development of this Organization came in 2010 when West Nile civil society organizations identified the Organization to Coordinate We Can Campaign Project Funded by Oxfam in West Nile, (thus bringing all West Nile GBV actors together both state and none state Actors) a program that ran for 6 years in which AHEDI-UG mobilized and brought together 169 state and non-state GBV actors and with them, recruited 16,000 charge makers across all the districts of West Nile Nile. Although the project ended, AHEDI- UG  has managed to sustain this members through various advocacy engagements resulting to enactments of 7 (seven) district level ordinances to address a base line campaign findings carried in 2013 under Oxfam funded We Can Campaign.To date, AHEDI- UG has continued to build on this coalition to address GBV issues in the region and now, the Organization is, in Partnership with EU, implementing 923,730,000/ project to empower Women Market vendors in Arua District to end GBV, a project that arose out of We Can Campaign Base line survey supra.1.ACHIEVEMENTSToday AHEDI-UG in partnership with Arua district Local government is providing technical assistance to the District council and has being charged by council to guide and ensure production of Alcohol Control Ordinance, Charcoal and wood fuelcontrol Ordinance and Education Ordinance Amendment Bill 2018. The same partnership is with the districts of Maracha and Koboko on Education, Food security and Local Council Court Committee Development Training. This is an achievement for us in the area of Policy and legal support to Local Governments to address issues of GBV policy gaps.AHEDI-UG continued to work with ELNHA members to address emergency refugee issues in the settlement, with a support from Oxfam through CEFORD and played amajor role in the period when host communities rose against the relief aid workers in Oriama, Imvepi and Rigbo sub counties. This was successful interventions that restore peace and harmony among the actors. This intervention achieved AHEDI-UG strategic objectiveforpeaceful resolution of conflicts as opposed to court litigation and war in the region of operationToday with funding support from EU, AHEDI-UG targets to transform 14 VSLA#s in to cooperative societies so that they have legal status to compete and win funds from government programs and have capacity  to defend, protect and jointly advocate for their rights under one umbrella.3.    INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSEMission: Mission: What is the current purpose of the organisation?AHEDI-UG vision is that all women, girls and men alike live in peaceful and just environment where enjoyment of human rights is promoted, defended and protectedInstitutional objectives: Five years vision for AHEDI-UG.CONTEXTIn the year 2020 greater acceptance and full inclusion by the community, improved services and more prevalence will be added socio-economic quality of women, children and other special interest groups of persons affected and infected HIV/AIDs, PWDs and indigent persons.At the same time, because of population growth, the ageing population and higher incidences of multiple diagnoses, the rights of women, girls, children and other indigent persons will remain extensive and varied.While significant strives will have been made in observance of the rights of women and girls, and to bridge the gap in implementation of Domestic laws and policies in protecting, promoting and defending the rights of women and other vulnerable persons in the community, there will be an ongoing push for community inclusion and participation.Finally women and other special interest groups of persons like affected and infected with HIV/AIDs, PWDs and indigent persons will control more resources and decisions about who provide them with help and support.Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisationworks?  Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?ROLE AND PROGRRAMME SERVICESAction for Human Rights and Education Initiative #Uganda is the lead in bringing up communities in identifying needs and all kinds of resources and services for her primaryand secondary beneficiaries to support full long term community inclusion of women and other vulnerable persons in determining their destiny and choice of life. Specifically AHEDI-UG will:-# Lead collaboration of providers and community groups /organizations, government departments and programs in the region and from surrounding areas, as appropriate, identifying needs and gaps in the services.# Directly provide cutting#edge, model services that meet identified gaps.# AHEDI-UG may not strive to provide comprehensive services itself BUT direct services it does provide are of the highest quality.# Collaborates with and make key referrals to  other high quality services providers and# Lead many advocacy efforts to ensure services are provided either by AHEDI-UG or other providers.# AHEDI-UG will play a leadership role in advocating at all levels of government, and with private sector and the public at largefor elimination of GBV and VAW, promote food security and nutrition, water and sanitation in the community and general awareness creation in human rights and fundamental freedoms of persons affected and infected with HIV/AIDs most especially women and children.# Encourage and support victims of GBV and VAW in pursuing this advocacy agenda.4. STRATEGIC POSITIONINGAnalyse the environment inwhich the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? '  In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation?MISSION OF AHEDI-UGAchieving full personal human life for women, girls and other vulnerable community members and create an environment          1.  Addressing women and girls accessto justice and challenging the concept of socio- economic practices that perpetrate domestic violence and violence against women through application of religious, cultural and traditional laws.2. Strengthening the rights basedapproach and human rights monitoringcapacities for women groups/ organisation and persons affected and infected with HIV/ AIDS at grass root levels.3. Engaging district leadership in the West Nile region build capacity to reduce GENDER and other disparities in relation to increased access to and completion of quality basic education through promotion of girl child education.4. Engaging both political and civic leadership in West Nile region to address disparity between existing policies and domesticlaws with practices in the communities in specific reference to women#s socio economic rights.5. Recognising, supporting and protecting women working in the informal sector livelihood and promoting their economic roles in the society.

description_narrative: AHEDI together with Arua district NGO Network and Manyak Anti Corruption Coalition will implement the COVID-19 project under ELNHA under the following activities:The activities are aimed at enriching stakeholder knowledge on COVID-19 so as to influence their perceptions and beliefs on the pandemic and foster positive change for effective control of the disease. The action embraces two approaches:  behavior change communication and improved health promotional and personal hygiene practices. It extendsto cover prevention and response address the needs of those affected by the pandemic.A: Prevention1. COVID-19 aligned behavior change information communication, health education and personal hygiene promotion. This sensitization is intended to create awareness on COVID-19, the virus and the disease, how it spreads and its prevention. This will create the critical mass of knowledge for appropriate decision making and behavior change required to effectively fight the pandemic. Planned activities are:1.1. Conduct live spot community healthand personal hygiene education: Sensitization programs will be run to educate the community on COVID-19. This will involve:1.1.1.Door-to-door sensitization: The team will be equipped with key information on COVID-19 required for effective control of the pandemic. The educators will be examined prior to field excursion for assurance that they are not infected and will not pose a risk to thecommunity. They will be equipped with personal protection equipments like facial masks and sanitizers to protect them against risksin the field.1.1.2 Radio programs: Topical issues will be identified and aired on radio for mass sensitization. This will use both English and local languages most commonly used in the communitya. Radio talk shows will be organized and facilitated by health experts with grounding in public health and strong knowledge on COVID-19b. Radio spots messages will be constructed based on a mix of technical matters, community perceptionsand behavioral constructs and will be played on radio throughout the implementation period of the action. This will help to keep information on the pandemic alive throughout the implementation period. The messages may be reviewed and updated as and when new facts and perceptions arise so as to keep the spots message relevant.1.1.3. Boda boda talk-talk: Sensitization messages with detailed information on COVID-19 response protocol including statistical facts on prevalence of the pandemic as well as ministerial policy issues and guidance will be packaged, recorded and played on moving vehicles and motorcycles around town, in the villages and settlements to reinforce sensitization program on radio. This will help to reach the vulnerable communities thatcannot afford radios.1.1.4. Print and distribute public health information on COVID-19: This action will use the information already provided by international agencies, national authorities and health experts to:a. Translate advisories, protocolsandadvocacy messages COVID-19:  key messages made available by WHO, MoH, Oxfam and other humanitarian platforms on COVID-19 will be translated in to three (3) local languages namely: Arabic, Lugbara, Kakwa). This will localize the literature on COVID-19for easier and wider reading and reception among the lowly educated local population. The information will then be disseminated to communities both in print and on air:b. Print and distribute advisories, protocols and advocacy messages on COVID-19: Key messages on COVID-19 both in their original English version and translated versions will be printed and distributed to make information on COVID-19 available in the community at all times. This will continuously keep information on the pandemic alive in thecommunity and maintain community consciousness on COVID-19 at all timesi. Flyers will be printed for distribution to individuals. This will carry the message up to  household levelii. Banners will be produced on water-proof materials and displayed at public places like women centers, schools, markets, places of worship and offices. This will stay and carry information on COVID-19 displayed and visible for a longer time in the community. Its attractive nature will compel more people to read the messages.1.1.5. Social media engagement: Mass social media platforms will be created for targeted mobilization and sensitization.  Key advocacy messages made available on COVID-19 by WHO, MoH, Oxfam and other humanitarian platforms will be imputed and disseminated on the mass social media platforms.a. Bulk SMS messaging: An SMS platform will be created for mass mobilization, sensitization and surveillance on COVID-19. Community members will be recruited on to the platform and be sensitized on useof the platform. Pre-payments will be made under the Action for use of the platform, so sending messages on to the platform will be free of charge. This will enable vulnerable communities effectively use the platform for accessing and sending messages onCOVID-19. This is particularly important in surveillance since it will help communitiesin reporting suspected cases on time.b. Virtual conferences on COVID-19 topical issues:A multi-task social media platform will becreated for key actors notably members ofinteragency and district task forces on COVID-19, project staff and key local authorities.Virtual conferences will then be supported for targeted rapid mobilization and response among the members. It will be used to facilitate dissemination of new emerging issues and support discussion of status reports and reviews. In so doing it will help in effectual management of the pandemic while maintaining the physical distance recommendations by WHO, MoH and humanitarian platforms on COVID-19. In this action,Whatsapp, Skype and Zoomed platforms will be particularly used.1.2. Institutional health promotion and advocacy on COVIG-19: Once the government waives the suspension on public gatherings, places of crowd and social services remain high at risk becauseof the numbers of people and movement involved. The action will carry out targeted hygiene promotion, education and sensitization in schools market centers and places of worship.a. Health talks: Key messages on COVID-19 will be packaged for school children,market goers and followers in the various places of worship and delivered using the project team, and authorities in the facilities in coordinated mannerb. Distribution of advisories, protocols and advocacy messages on COVID-19: The printedcopies of thekey messages on COVID-19 will be distributed and displayed at schools, market centers and places of worship to make information on COVID-19 available in the public places at all times. This will continuously keep information on the pandemicalive inthe public places and maintain consciousness among the facility users on COVID-19 at all timesi. Flyers will be distributed facility users.ii. Banners will be produced on water-proof materials and displayed at the public places schools, market centers andplaces of worship. This will stay and carry information on COVID-19 displayed and visible for a longer time in the facilities and among the facility users.1.3. Public health and hygiene promotion1.3.1 Procure and distribute hygiene promotional facilities: In addition to the behavior change communication and education or sensitization for personal and institutional hygiene promotion, hygiene promotional facilities will be procured and distributed to schools, administrative centers, market centersand places worship as well as centers of high daily population concentrations like food distribution centers and community meeting centers. This will help to support required hygiene promotional practices notably hand washing and curb spread of coronavirus andother hygiene related diseases.a. Procure and install masshand washing cans: These will be distributed to schools, administrative centers, market centers and places of worship as well as centers of high daily population concentrations like food distribution centers and community meeting centers to help support hand washing in the centers.b. Procure and distribute water delivery jerry cans: These will be complimentary to hand washing cans and is intended to facilitate water collection from the nearest source for delivery to the hand washing point where the cans are installed.c.Procure and distribute soap and detergents: These will be complimentary to hand washing cans and help to clean and/or disinfect thehand. Preference will be given to liquid soapfor public use. Alcohol based sanitizers will only be delivered to key actors who continuously get engaged in response activities under COVID-19 response or other humanitarian responses like food destruction1.3.2 Cashtransfer to community members involved in installing mass hand washing cans: In consultation with the local authorities, women and youth will be identified among the community members to construct and install basements for the mass hand washing cans. This will foster women and youth involvement and participation in COVID-19 response.B: Response2 In the event COVID-19 strikes, several medical care, social and economic needs become eminent. Those affected will suffer stigma, emotional to physical violence and economic hardships andhumanitarian systems will be over stressed. Under this action, support will be given to those affected and their families/dependants in order to assist them access medical care and build resilience. Support will also be given to strengthen the existinghealth system for improved response2.1. Complementary support to existing health system in care and treatment of COVID-19 cases:2.1.1 Procure and distribute basic equipments and sundries for COVID-19 treatment: Key equipment and sundries will be procuredand distrusted to health facilities designated to manage COVID-19 cases.i. Procure and distribute anti-bacterial hospital mattresses: These will be distributed to health centers designated as COVID-19 treatment centers for the patients andthose quarantined after havinghad contacts with infected persons.ii. Procure and distribute N95 facial masts: These will be used to protect the health workers and other responders in the COVID-19 pandemiciii. Procure and install hand washing cans: These will bedistributed to health centers to support hand washing in the facilitiesiv. Procure and distribute water delivery jerry cans: These will facilitate water collection from the nearest source for delivery to the hand washing point where the cans are installed.v. Procure and distribute soap and detergents: These will be used to clean and/or disinfect the hand.2.1.2. Support to those directly affected by COVID-19i. Provide psychosocial support for those affected and their families:Once infected byCOVID-19,those affected and their immediate families will fall victim to discrimination and associated stigma. Psychosocial support will help to mitigate the negative impact of COVIC-19 on those affected by the disease and their dear ones.2.1.3. Surveillance: Ascontagious disease, information on all cases whether suspected or real will be collected and referred to designated health facilities for verification. Community perceptions and social behavior that are likely to propagate spread of thediseasewillalso bemonitored and acted upon. The surveillance will involve close collaboration and coordination with the existing health system and task forces already built on COVID-19. Information gained from the communities will be followed for verificationand cases referred using the established referral system to designated facilities for further managementa. Data capture and follow-ups on cases reported from communities: The action will institute effective surveillance system for information capture and follow-uponcases reported from communities. This will partly use the mass SMS platform created underactivity 1.1.5a.above. It will use the health structures in place to support the project team. Information captured will be recorded and updated regularly to produce weekly or monthly COVID-19status reportsb. Contact tracing: All persons established to have comeinto contact with confirmed COVID-19 cases (patients) will be followed and presented for screening. Similarly, persons suspected tohave come fromareas rated as high risk will be followed-up and presented for screening and/or quarantine3.  Other activities directly linked to the responseThis action will be delivered in close collaboration and coordination with local districtand interagencytaskforces, the local authorities and full involvement of the target beneficiaries in the Arua district.. The overall progress of the response and implementation of activities will be closely monitored and regularly reviewed toenable good follow-up actions to beinstituted and achieve the desired objective of preventing COVID-19 incidence in the community.3.1. Project inception: Project inception meeting will be held with members of the district and interagency task force,local authorities andrepresentativesof the beneficiary community.3.2. Monitoring and Evaluationa. Conduct routine field monitoring visits and follow-ups: A data base will be created to capture information on COVID19 and project implementation progress. Information on the status of COVID-19willbe routinely captured and entered on to the data base on daily basis. In case of any reported cases of coronavirus disease, the actions taken and findings will accordingly be updated on the database. This information may be received directlyfromthe community or through the project staff in the field. Similarly, information on the project implementation progress will be routinely captured and entered on to the data base on daily basis and be used for makingprogress reports and corrective action memos.b.Conduct weekly reviews: The data captured in Activity 3.1 above will be collated and summarized to develop weekly reports. This will be used to facilitate weekly review meetings by the project team. Members of the interagency and district task forces maybe invited to attend the reviews if the circumstance warrants so.c. Facilitate project team to attend interagency review meetings on COVID-19: Core project staffs (Project Manager, Surveillance focal person and MEALOfficer) will be facilitated to attend interagency task force meetings on COVID-19.The team willalso attend such meetings as may be convened by district task force on COVID-19.d. Conduct project end evaluation meeting: At the end, a terminal evaluation will be conducted to assess thecontribution of the project towards managing the COVID-19 pandemic. This evaluation meeting will draw participants from the interagency task force on COVID-19, the district task force, key local authoritiesand the project team.Monitoring andEvaluation#weekly reviewso Stationeryo Refreshmentso Airtime for coordination# Interagencyreview meetingso Fuelo SDAo Air time for coordinationQuarterly stakeholder review meetingsPsychosocial supportIssueso Economichardship (people livingon hand-to-mouth, economic growth affected by 3%)o Emotional violenceo Stigma (prevents people from showing up and declare their status)o Physical assault (5 women murdered # police report)# Contacttracingo Fuelo Air timeo SDAoDocumentation (stationery# Surveillanceo Fuelo Air timeo SDA

Boda boda talk-talk: Sensitization messages with detailed information on COVID-19 response protocol including statistical facts on prevalence of the pandemic as well as ministerial policy issues and guidance will be packaged, recorded and played on moving vehicles and motorcycles around town, in the villages and settlements to reinforce sensitization program on radio. This will help to reach the vulnerable communities thatcannot afford radios.1.1.4. Print and distribute public health information on COVID-19: This action will use the information already provided by international agencies, national authorities and health experts to:a. Translate advisories, protocolsandadvocacy messages COVID-19:  key messages made available by WHO, MoH, Oxfam and other humanitarian platforms on COVID-19 will be translated in to three (3) local languages namely: Arabic, Lugbara, Kakwa). This will localize the literature on COVID-19for easier and wider reading and reception among the lowly educated local population. The information will then be disseminated to communities both in print and on air:b. Print and distribute advisories, protocols and advocacy messages on COVID-19: Key messages on COVID-19 both in their original English version and translated versions will be printed and distributed to make information on COVID-19 available in the community at all times. This will continuously keep information on the pandemic alive in thecommunity and maintain community consciousness on COVID-19 at all timesi. Flyers will be printed for distribution to individuals. This will carry the message up to  household levelii. Banners will be produced on water-proof materials and displayed at public places like women centers, schools, markets, places of worship and offices. This will stay and carry information on COVID-19 displayed and visible for a longer time in the community. Its attractive nature will compel more people to read the messages.1.1.5. Social media engagement: Mass social media platforms will be created for targeted mobilization and sensitization.  Key advocacy messages made available on COVID-19 by WHO, MoH, Oxfam and other humanitarian platforms will be imputed and disseminated on the mass social media platforms.a. Bulk SMS messaging: An SMS platform will be created for mass mobilization, sensitization and surveillance on COVID-19. Community members will be recruited on to the platform and be sensitized on useof the platform. Pre-payments will be made under the Action for use of the platform, so sending messages on to the platform will be free of charge. This will enable vulnerable communities effectively use the platform for accessing and sending messages onCOVID-19. This is particularly important in surveillance since it will help communitiesin reporting suspected cases on time.b. Virtual conferences on COVID-19 topical issues:A multi-task social media platform will becreated for key actors notably members ofinteragency and district task forces on COVID-19, project staff and key local authorities.Virtual conferences will then be supported for targeted rapid mobilization and response among the members. It will be used to facilitate dissemination of new emerging issues and support discussion of status reports and reviews. In so doing it will help in effectual management of the pandemic while maintaining the physical distance recommendations by WHO, MoH and humanitarian platforms on COVID-19. In this action,Whatsapp, Skype and Zoomed platforms will be particularly used.1.2. Institutional health promotion and advocacy on COVIG-19: Once the government waives the suspension on public gatherings, places of crowd and social services remain high at risk becauseof the numbers of people and movement involved. The action will carry out targeted hygiene promotion, education and sensitization in schools market centers and places of worship.a. Health talks: Key messages on COVID-19 will be packaged for school children,market goers and followers in the various places of worship and delivered using the project team, and authorities in the facilities in coordinated mannerb. Distribution of advisories, protocols and advocacy messages on COVID-19: The printedcopies of thekey messages on COVID-19 will be distributed and displayed at schools, market centers and places of worship to make information on COVID-19 available in the public places at all times. This will continuously keep information on the pandemicalive inthe public places and maintain consciousness among the facility users on COVID-19 at all timesi. Flyers will be distributed facility users.ii. Banners will be produced on water-proof materials and displayed at the public places schools, market centers andplaces of worship. This will stay and carry information on COVID-19 displayed and visible for a longer time in the facilities and among the facility users.1.3. Public health and hygiene promotion1.3.1 Procure and distribute hygiene promotional facilities: In addition to the behavior change communication and education or sensitization for personal and institutional hygiene promotion, hygiene promotional facilities will be procured and distributed to schools, administrative centers, market centersand places worship as well as centers of high daily population concentrations like food distribution centers and community meeting centers. This will help to support required hygiene promotional practices notably hand washing and curb spread of coronavirus andother hygiene related diseases.a. Procure and install masshand washing cans: These will be distributed to schools, administrative centers, market centers and places of worship as well as centers of high daily population concentrations like food distribution centers and community meeting centers to help support hand washing in the centers.b. Procure and distribute water delivery jerry cans: These will be complimentary to hand washing cans and is intended to facilitate water collection from the nearest source for delivery to the hand washing point where the cans are installed.c.Procure and distribute soap and detergents: These will be complimentary to hand washing cans and help to clean and/or disinfect thehand. Preference will be given to liquid soapfor public use. Alcohol based sanitizers will only be delivered to key actors who continuously get engaged in response activities under COVID-19 response or other humanitarian responses like food destruction1.3.2 Cashtransfer to community members involved in installing mass hand washing cans: In consultation with the local authorities, women and youth will be identified among the community members to construct and install basements for the mass hand washing cans. This will foster women and youth involvement and participation in COVID-19 response.B: Response2 In the event COVID-19 strikes, several medical care, social and economic needs become eminent. Those affected will suffer stigma, emotional to physical violence and economic hardships andhumanitarian systems will be over stressed. Under this action, support will be given to those affected and their families/dependants in order to assist them access medical care and build resilience. Support will also be given to strengthen the existinghealth system for improved response2.1. Complementary support to existing health system in care and treatment of COVID-19 cases:2.1.1 Procure and distribute basic equipments and sundries for COVID-19 treatment: Key equipment and sundries will be procuredand distrusted to health facilities designated to manage COVID-19 cases.i. Procure and distribute anti-bacterial hospital mattresses: These will be distributed to health centers designated as COVID-19 treatment centers for the patients andthose quarantined after havinghad contacts with infected persons.ii. Procure and distribute N95 facial masts: These will be used to protect the health workers and other responders in the COVID-19 pandemiciii. Procure and install hand washing cans: These will bedistributed to health centers to support hand washing in the facilitiesiv. Procure and distribute water delivery jerry cans: These will facilitate water collection from the nearest source for delivery to the hand washing point where the cans are installed.v. Procure and distribute soap and detergents: These will be used to clean and/or disinfect the hand.2.1.2. Support to those directly affected by COVID-19i. Provide psychosocial support for those affected and their families:Once infected byCOVID-19,those affected and their immediate families will fall victim to discrimination and associated stigma. Psychosocial support will help to mitigate the negative impact of COVIC-19 on those affected by the disease and their dear ones.2.1.3. Surveillance: Ascontagious disease, information on all cases whether suspected or real will be collected and referred to designated health facilities for verification. Community perceptions and social behavior that are likely to propagate spread of thediseasewillalso bemonitored and acted upon. The surveillance will involve close collaboration and coordination with the existing health system and task forces already built on COVID-19. Information gained from the communities will be followed for verificationand cases referred using the established referral system to designated facilities for further managementa. Data capture and follow-ups on cases reported from communities: The action will institute effective surveillance system for information capture and follow-uponcases reported from communities. This will partly use the mass SMS platform created underactivity 1.1.5a.above. It will use the health structures in place to support the project team. Information captured will be recorded and updated regularly to produce weekly or monthly COVID-19status reportsb. Contact tracing: All persons established to have comeinto contact with confirmed COVID-19 cases (patients) will be followed and presented for screening. Similarly, persons suspected tohave come fromareas rated as high risk will be followed-up and presented for screening and/or quarantine3.  Other activities directly linked to the responseThis action will be delivered in close collaboration and coordination with local districtand interagencytaskforces, the local authorities and full involvement of the target beneficiaries in the Arua district.. The overall progress of the response and implementation of activities will be closely monitored and regularly reviewed toenable good follow-up actions to beinstituted and achieve the desired objective of preventing COVID-19 incidence in the community.3.1. Project inception: Project inception meeting will be held with members of the district and interagency task force,local authorities andrepresentativesof the beneficiary community.3.2. Monitoring and Evaluationa. Conduct routine field monitoring visits and follow-ups: A data base will be created to capture information on COVID19 and project implementation progress. Information on the status of COVID-19willbe routinely captured and entered on to the data base on daily basis. In case of any reported cases of coronavirus disease, the actions taken and findings will accordingly be updated on the database. This information may be received directlyfromthe community or through the project staff in the field. Similarly, information on the project implementation progress will be routinely captured and entered on to the data base on daily basis and be used for makingprogress reports and corrective action memos.b.Conduct weekly reviews: The data captured in Activity 3.1 above will be collated and summarized to develop weekly reports. This will be used to facilitate weekly review meetings by the project team. Members of the interagency and district task forces maybe invited to attend the reviews if the circumstance warrants so.c. Facilitate project team to attend interagency review meetings on COVID-19: Core project staffs (Project Manager, Surveillance focal person and MEALOfficer) will be facilitated to attend interagency task force meetings on COVID-19.The team willalso attend such meetings as may be convened by district task force on COVID-19.d. Conduct project end evaluation meeting: At the end, a terminal evaluation will be conducted to assess thecontribution of the project towards managing the COVID-19 pandemic. This evaluation meeting will draw participants from the interagency task force on COVID-19, the district task force, key local authoritiesand the project team.Monitoring andEvaluation#weekly reviewso Stationeryo Refreshmentso Airtime for coordination# Interagencyreview meetingso Fuelo SDAo Air time for coordinationQuarterly stakeholder review meetingsPsychosocial supportIssueso Economichardship (people livingon hand-to-mouth, economic growth affected by 3%)o Emotional violenceo Stigma (prevents people from showing up and declare their status)o Physical assault (5 women murdered # police report)# Contacttracingo Fuelo Air timeo SDAoDocumentation (stationery# Surveillanceo Fuelo Air timeo SDA

participating_org_narrative: ACTION 4 HUMAN RIGHTS & EDUCATION I AHEDI

AHEDI- UG is an Organization formed by young university graduates in the field of law and social work in July 2008 to promote, defend and protect rights of every citizen regardless of tribe and nationality; #Justice for All#. The organization has mainstreamed itsactivities in the area of GBV/VAWG, PHA victims, Women and children in conflict with the law, Land rights, Legal and social consultancy for Local governments (on Policy and legal Issues) and other vulnerable persons, working towards improving the legal framework and awareness on human rights and fundamental freedom, land and property rights.AHEDI-UG delivers holistic and citizen friendly programs with particular emphasis on GBV/VAWG,HIV/AIDs, emergency response to humanitarian issues, land rights/property ownership, psycho-social support, legal and social consultancy that leads to  sustainable development and livelihood.AHEDI-UG works with a number of partners in the execution of its mission including political and technocrats at the districts of west Nile sub region and Uganda at large, members of parliament (MP), traditional leaders, central government representatives, other NGOs, CBOs and Faith base leaders among others.The turning point in the development of this Organization came in 2010 when West Nile civil society organizations identified the Organization to Coordinate We Can Campaign Project Funded by Oxfam in West Nile, (thus bringing all West Nile GBV actors together both state and none state Actors) a program that ran for 6 years in which AHEDI-UG mobilized and brought together 169 state and non-state GBV actors and with them, recruited 16,000 charge makers across all the districts of West Nile Nile. Although the project ended, AHEDI- UG  has managed to sustain this members through various advocacy engagements resulting to enactments of 7 (seven) district level ordinances to address a base line campaign findings carried in 2013 under Oxfam funded We Can Campaign.To date, AHEDI- UG has continued to build on this coalition to address GBV issues in the region and now, the Organization is, in Partnership with EU, implementing 923,730,000/ project to empower Women Market vendors in Arua District to end GBV, a project that arose out of We Can Campaign Base line survey supra.1.ACHIEVEMENTSToday AHEDI-UG in partnership with Arua district Local government is providing technical assistance to the District council and has being charged by council to guide and ensure production of Alcohol Control Ordinance, Charcoal and wood fuelcontrol Ordinance and Education Ordinance Amendment Bill 2018. The same partnership is with the districts of Maracha and Koboko on Education, Food security and Local Council Court Committee Development Training. This is an achievement for us in the area of Policy and legal support to Local Governments to address issues of GBV policy gaps.AHEDI-UG continued to work with ELNHA members to address emergency refugee issues in the settlement, with a support from Oxfam through CEFORD and played amajor role in the period when host communities rose against the relief aid workers in Oriama, Imvepi and Rigbo sub counties. This was successful interventions that restore peace and harmony among the actors. This intervention achieved AHEDI-UG strategic objectiveforpeaceful resolution of conflicts as opposed to court litigation and war in the region of operationToday with funding support from EU, AHEDI-UG targets to transform 14 VSLA#s in to cooperative societies so that they have legal status to compete and win funds from government programs and have capacity  to defend, protect and jointly advocate for their rights under one umbrella.3.    INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSEMission: Mission: What is the current purpose of the organisation?AHEDI-UG vision is that all women, girls and men alike live in peaceful and just environment where enjoyment of human rights is promoted, defended and protectedInstitutional objectives: Five years vision for AHEDI-UG.CONTEXTIn the year 2020 greater acceptance and full inclusion by the community, improved services and more prevalence will be added socio-economic quality of women, children and other special interest groups of persons affected and infected HIV/AIDs, PWDs and indigent persons.At the same time, because of population growth, the ageing population and higher incidences of multiple diagnoses, the rights of women, girls, children and other indigent persons will remain extensive and varied.While significant strives will have been made in observance of the rights of women and girls, and to bridge the gap in implementation of Domestic laws and policies in protecting, promoting and defending the rights of women and other vulnerable persons in the community, there will be an ongoing push for community inclusion and participation.Finally women and other special interest groups of persons like affected and infected with HIV/AIDs, PWDs and indigent persons will control more resources and decisions about who provide them with help and support.Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisationworks?  Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?ROLE AND PROGRRAMME SERVICESAction for Human Rights and Education Initiative #Uganda is the lead in bringing up communities in identifying needs and all kinds of resources and services for her primaryand secondary beneficiaries to support full long term community inclusion of women and other vulnerable persons in determining their destiny and choice of life. Specifically AHEDI-UG will:-# Lead collaboration of providers and community groups /organizations, government departments and programs in the region and from surrounding areas, as appropriate, identifying needs and gaps in the services.# Directly provide cutting#edge, model services that meet identified gaps.# AHEDI-UG may not strive to provide comprehensive services itself BUT direct services it does provide are of the highest quality.# Collaborates with and make key referrals to  other high quality services providers and# Lead many advocacy efforts to ensure services are provided either by AHEDI-UG or other providers.# AHEDI-UG will play a leadership role in advocating at all levels of government, and with private sector and the public at largefor elimination of GBV and VAW, promote food security and nutrition, water and sanitation in the community and general awareness creation in human rights and fundamental freedoms of persons affected and infected with HIV/AIDs most especially women and children.# Encourage and support victims of GBV and VAW in pursuing this advocacy agenda.4. STRATEGIC POSITIONINGAnalyse the environment inwhich the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? '  In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation?MISSION OF AHEDI-UGAchieving full personal human life for women, girls and other vulnerable community members and create an environment          1.  Addressing women and girls accessto justice and challenging the concept of socio- economic practices that perpetrate domestic violence and violence against women through application of religious, cultural and traditional laws.2. Strengthening the rights basedapproach and human rights monitoringcapacities for women groups/ organisation and persons affected and infected with HIV/ AIDS at grass root levels.3. Engaging district leadership in the West Nile region build capacity to reduce GENDER and other disparities in relation to increased access to and completion of quality basic education through promotion of girl child education.4. Engaging both political and civic leadership in West Nile region to address disparity between existing policies and domesticlaws with practices in the communities in specific reference to women#s socio economic rights.5. Recognising, supporting and protecting women working in the informal sector livelihood and promoting their economic roles in the society.

title_narrative: Seychelles - COVID-19 Crisis Response Budget Support Program
Seychelles - Programme d’appui budgétaire en réponse à la crise de la COVID-19
description_narrative: The proposed operation is a loan to the Republic of Seychelles for USD 10 million to finance the COVID-19 emergency response support program. This is a Crisis Response Budget Support (CRBS) that will be applied for 12 months from June 2020 to July 2021. The Seychelles Crisis Response Budget Support operation was appraised from 20 – 27 April 2020 following a request from the Republic of Seychelles dated 8 April 2020. Seychelles faces a dual challenge of addressing short term impact of COVID-19 and setting the course for a higher growth trajectory. The first case of COVID-19 in Seychelles was confirmed on 14th March and by the 6th of April, there were 11 confirmed imported cases. The country has attained universal health coverage (UHC) with the State providing free and universal access to health care for all Seychellois. However, COVID-19 pandemic threatens to reverse these gains and risks the sustainability of Seychelles universal health coverage. Cognizant of this threat, the Government is implementing measures under the COVID-19 National Response Plan, which have been effective in preventing community transmissions. The operation is to support Government actions that will lay the foundation for macroeconomic stability and protect the socioeconomic progress that the country has so far achieved. The program consists of three broad components namely: (i) strengthening the health response for COVID-19; (ii) expanding social protection and protecting livelihoods against COVID-19 impact; and (iii) protecting economic activities and safeguarding jobs against COVID-19 shocks. These three components are interlinked in pursuit of addressing the immediate public health challenge of saving lives, expanding social protection mechanisms as well as cushioning businesses and the economy from downward spiral.

La présente interventionporte sur un prêt de 10 millions d’USD à la République des Seychelles pour financer le programme d’appui à la riposte d’urgence à la COVID-19. Il s’agit d’un appui budgétaire en réponse à la crise (ABRC) qui s’étendra sur 12 mois, de juin 2020 à juillet 2021. L’appui budgétaire pour la réponse aux crises aux Seychelles été évaluée du 20 au 27 avril 2020 suite à une demande de la République des Seychelles datée du 8 avril 2020. Les Seychelles sont confrontées à un double défi consistant à atténuer l’impact à court terme de la COVID 19 et à définir la voie à suivre pour se placer sur une trajectoire de plus forte croissance. Le premier cas de COVID-19 a été confirmé aux Seychelles le 14 mars et 11 cas importés avaient été confirmés au 6 avril, aucun décès n’étant enregistré. Le pays est parvenu à une couverture médicale universelle, l’État offrant un accès gratuit et uniforme aux soins de santé à tous les Seychellois. La pandémie de COVID-19 menace toutefois de réduire à néant les progrès réalisés par le système de santé publique, car une pandémie généralisée et prolongée pourrait entraîner des dépenses de santé élevées et compromettre la viabilité de la couverture sanitaire universelle. Conscient de cette menace, le gouvernement met en œuvre, dans le cadre du plan national de riposte à la COVID-19, des mesures qui ont été efficaces pour prévenir les transmissions communautaires. L’opération est destinée à appuyer les mesures gouvernementales qui jetteront les bases de la stabilité macroéconomique, et à préserver les avancées socio-économiques réalisées jusqu’ici par le pays. Le programme comprend trois composantes générales, à savoir : i) renforcer la riposte sanitaire à la COVID-19?; ii) étendre la protection sociale et préserver les moyens de subsistance contre l’impact de la COVID-19?; et iii) protéger les activités économiques et préserver les emplois contre les chocs de la COVID-19. Ces trois composantes sont étroitement liées pour relever le défi immédiat de santé publique consistant à sauver des vies, à étendre les mécanismes de protection sociale et à protéger les entreprises et l’économie contre la spirale descendante.

The goal of the operation is to support Seychelles’ National COVID-19 response policies and plans to contain and mitigate the social and economic impacts of COVID-19 pandemic. The policy objective of the operation is to; (i) strengthen the health response to COVID-19 pandemic; (ii) protect livelihoods and enhance social protection measures against COVID19, and; (iii) minimize risk to macroeconomic stability and create resilience for economic activities.

L’opération a pour but d’appuyer les politiques et plans nationaux de riposte à la COVID-19 des Seychelles destinés à contenir la pandémie et à atténuer les effets sociaux et économiques de la pandémie de COVID-19. L’objectif stratégique visé par l’opération est i) de renforcer la riposte sanitaire à la pandémie de COVID-19 et d’arrêter la propagation de nouvelles infections, ii) de protéger les moyens de subsistance et de renforcer les mesures de protection sociale contre la COVID-19, et iii) de réduire au minimum le risque pour la stabilité macroéconomique et de rendre résilientes les activités économiques.

The program will protect the population from the spread of COVID19 especially men who are epidemiologically more susceptible and enhanced fiscal space for improved basic service delivery. The poor and vulnerable whose livelihoods have been affected by the pandemic will directly benefit through strengthened livelihoods and expanded social protection coverage. Employees in the private sector will also benefit through the government’s salary guarantee scheme. Maintained macroeconomic stability supported by the program will directly benefit households, the private sector and financial sector actors through faster and more inclusive economic recovery on the back of more resilient businesses and workforce.

Le programme protégera la population de la propagation du COVID-19, en particulier des hommes qui sont épidémiologiques plus sensibles, et améliorera l’espace fiscal pour améliorer la prestation des services de base. La population sera protégée contre les effets de la pandémie de COVID-19. Les pauvres et les personnes vulnérables dont les moyens de subsistance ont été touchés par la pandémie en profiteront directement, grâce au renforcement des moyens de subsistance et à l’extension de la couverture de protection sociale. Les employés du secteur privé tireront aussi parti du système de garantie des salaires mis en place par le gouvernement. Le maintien de la stabilité macroéconomique qu’appuie le programme profitera directement aux ménages, au secteur privé et aux acteurs du secteur financier, grâce à l’accélération et à une inclusivité accrue de la reprise économique, favorisées par le renforcement de la résilience des entreprises et de la main-d’œuvre.

title_narrative: Ethiopia - COVID-19 Crisis Response Budget Support Program (ECRBS)
Ethiopie - Programme d’appui budgétaire pour la riposte à la pandémie de COVID-19 (ECRBS)
description_narrative: The Ethiopia COVID-19 Crisis Response Budget Support (ECRBS) program aims to support the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia’s NERP to contain the spread of COVID-19 and to mitigate the economic and social impacts of the COVID19 pandemic on local businesses and vulnerable households, particularly the urban poor. Indeed, Ethiopia ranks among the few sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) countries that have halved poverty within a decade. As of end May 2020, 1,172 cases of COVID-19 had been reported in country, with 209 recoveries and 11 deaths. The impact of COVID-19 on Ethiopia’s economy is likely to be significant and may reverse some economic progress achieved. The operation consists of a UA 120 million grant from the country’s ADF-15 Performance Based Allocation to finance the Ethiopian Government’s COVID-19 National Emergency Response Plan (NERP). This is a Crisis Response Budget Support provided in compliance with the Bank Group’s COVID-19 Rapid Response Facility (CRF), approved by the Boards of the Bank and the Fund on 8th April 2020. This program consists of three broad mutually reinforcing components: (i) supporting the health sector response to COVID-19, (ii) supporting the social sector response program against COVID-19 and (iii) safeguarding economic resilience against the after-effects of COVID-19 shocks.

Le Programme d’appui budgétaire pour la riposte à la COVID-19 en Éthiopie (ECRBS) vise essentiellement à soutenir le Plan national de riposte d’urgence (NERP) de la République fédérale démocratique d’Éthiopie pour enrayer la propagation de la maladie à coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) et en atténuer les impacts économiques et sociaux sur les entreprises locales et les ménages vulnérables, et singulièrement sur les populations pauvres vivant dans les centres urbains. En effet, l’Éthiopie est l’un des rares pays d’Afrique subsaharienne à avoir réduit de moitié son taux de pauvreté en dix ans. À la fin du mois de mai 2020, en tout 1 172 cas de COVID-19 avaient été recensés dans le pays, au nombre desquels 209 cas guéris et 11 décès. L’impact de la COVID19 sur l’économie éthiopienne pourrait être important et compromettre certains progrès réalisés sur le plan économique. L’opération consiste en un don de 120 millions d’UC, de l'allocation du FAD-15 basée sur la performance, pour financer en partie le Plan national de riposte d’urgence à la COVID-19 (NERP). Il s’agit d’un appui budgétaire réalisé pour appuyer la riposte à la crise, conformément à la Facilité de réponse rapide à la COVID-19 (CRF) mise en place par le Groupe de la Banque et approuvée par les Conseils d’administration de la Banque et du Fonds le 8 avril 2020. Cette opération comporte les trois grandes composantes ci-après, qui se renforcent mutuellement : i) appui à la riposte du secteur de la santé à la COVID-19 ; ii) appui au Programme de riposte du secteur social à la COVID-19 ; et iii) renforcement de la résilience économique contre les répercussions de la COVID-19.

The goal of the program is to support the NERP, Ethiopia’s response plan to the COVID-19 pandemic, which includes strengthening of healthcare service preparedness and response, protection of livelihoods, especially for the vulnerable, and support to private sector enterprises. Consistent with the response plan, the overall operational objective of the proposed operation is to support the implementation of measures to ensure that the country’s healthcare and social protection systems, fiscal position and economy are sufficiently supported to mitigate the negative impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Le Programme a pour objectif de soutenir le NERP, le plan de riposte de l’Éthiopie à la pandémie de COVID-19, qui prévoit le renforcement de la préparation et de la riposte des services de santé, la protection des moyens de subsistance, en particulier pour les personnes vulnérables, et le soutien aux entreprises du secteur privé. Conformément au plan de riposte, l’objectif opérationnel global de l’opération proposée est d’accompagner la mise en œuvre de mesures visant à s’assurer que les systèmes de soins de santé et de protection sociale, la situation fiscale et l’économie du pays sont suffisamment soutenus pour atténuer les effets négatifs de la pandémie de COVID-19.

The program will benefit the Ethiopian people by contributing to protection of macroeconomic stability and supporting a more inclusive economic recovery. The direct beneficiaries from the program are households, private sector, financial sector actors and recipients of social protection grants, including orphans, the elderly, persons with disability and the urban poor. The program measures will also support strengthening capacity and expansion of health systems in order to improve and strengthen basic service delivery.

Le Programme profitera au peuple éthiopien en contribuant à la protection de la stabilité macroéconomique et en soutenant une reprise économique plus inclusive. Les bénéficiaires directs du Programme sont les ménages, le secteur privé, les acteurs du secteur financier et les bénéficiaires de subventions de protection sociale, en particulier les orphelins, les personnes âgées, les personnes handicapées et les pauvres vivant en milieu urbain. En outre, les mesures du Programme soutiendront le renforcement des capacités et l’expansion des systèmes de santé afin d’améliorer la prestation des services de base.

title_narrative: Sudan - COVID-19 Emergency Response Support Program (ERSP)
Soudan - Programme d’appui d’urgence à la riposte à la COVID-19 (ERSP)
description_narrative: The proposed operation is an ADF-15 grant of UA 18.75 million and TSF Pillar I grant of UA 1.25 million to the Republic of Sudan to finance operations of the Federal Ministry of Health of Sudan in response to the coronavirus disease (COVID- 19) pandemic across the country. The operation is aligned with Government of Sudan development objectives and COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Plan. It was appraised in June 2020 following a request from the Government of Sudan dated May 08, 2020. Indeed, Sudan experienced late transmission of COVID-19 and reported its first case on March 14, 2020. The numbers increased to 13,555 cases (6,759 recovered) and 836 deaths as at September 21, 2020. The project complements other COVID-19 response support that the Bank is providing to the East African Community (EAC), the InterGovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) and the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) under the auspices of the African Union (AU). The Sudan COVID-19 CRF will cover four components implemented at national and local levels. Its expected outcomes are enhanced capacity for treatment and care of COVID-19 patients; enhanced (national) capacity for testing, and surveillance for COVID-19; and heightened community awareness. The project will be implemented over one and half years (2020/2022) and its expected outcomes are enhanced capacity to contain COVID-19 and respond to future pandemics.

La présente intervention porte sur un don de 18,75 millions d’UC du FAD-15 et de 1,25 million d’UC du Pilier I de la FAT à la République fédérale du Soudan pour financer les opérations du ministère fédéral de la Santé en réponse à la pandémie de coronavirus (COVID-19) dans le pays. L’opération s’inscrit dans la ligne des objectifs de développement du gouvernement du Soudan et du plan de préparation et de réponse à la COVID-19. Elle a été évaluée en juin 2020 à la suite d’une demande du gouvernement du Soudan datée du 8 mai 2020. En effet, le Soudan a connu une transmission tardive de la COVID-19 et a signalé son premier cas le 14 mars 2020. Les chiffres sont passés à 13 555 cas (6 759 cas guéris) et 836 décès au 21 septembre 2020. Le projet complète les autres mesures de riposte à la pandémie de maladie à coronavirus 2019 offertes par la Banque par l’intermédiaire de la CAE, de l’IGAD et du Centre africain de contrôle et prévention des maladies (CDC) par l’intermédiaire de l’Union africaine. La CRF de la COVID-19 au Soudan couvrira quatre composantes mises en œuvre aux plans national et local. Les résultats escomptés sont l’amélioration des capacités de traitement et de soins des patients de la COVID-19, l’amélioration des capacités (nationales) de dépistage et de surveillance de la COVID-19 et la sensibilisation des communautés. Le projet sera mis en œuvre sur une période d’un an et demi (2020/2022) et devrait permettre de renforcer la capacité à contenir la COVID-19 et à répondre aux futures pandémies.

The goal of this project is to strengthen the health systems of Sudan to contain the COVID19 pandemic and build resilience to respond to future pandemics including climate-induced outbreaks. The project will support the Sudan COVID-19 pandemic preparedness and response plan in the following areas: (a) strengthen health systems and build resilience to respond to COVID-19 crisis and other pandemics taking into consideration the fragility of the country; (b) strengthen the laboratory testing and surveillance capacity; and (c) enhance community engagement and risk communication and positive health.

L’objectif de ce projet est de contribuer au « renforcement des systèmes de santé afin de contenir la pandémie de COVID-19 et de renforcer la résilience pour répondre aux futures pandémies, y compris les éclosions induites par le climat ». Le projet appuiera le plan de préparation et de réponse à la pandémie de COVID-19 au Soudan dans les domaines suivants : a) renforcer les systèmes de santé et développer la résilience pour répondre à la crise de COVID-19 et à d’autres épidémies en tenant compte de la fragilité du pays ; b) renforcer les capacités de surveillance et d’analyse en laboratoire ; et c) améliorer l’engagement communautaire et la communication des risques et la santé positive.

The direct beneficiaries of the program will be: (i) Sudan population who will benefit from improved access PHC services; (ii) the healthcare workers who will be trained on COVID-19 prevention and case management protocols; (iii) health workers in targeted health facilities (receive PPEs and reduced infection rates); (iv) the vulnerable and marginalized groups; and (v) positive cases who are critically affected by the disease. The indirect beneficiaries will be population in the 8 neighboring countries (subSaharan Africa and Arab world).

Les bénéficiaires directs du projet seront : i) la population soudanaise qui bénéficiera d’un meilleur accès aux services de soins de santé primaires ; ii) les travailleurs de la santé qui seront formés aux protocoles de prévention et de gestion des cas de COVID-19 ; iii) les travailleurs de la santé des établissements de santé ciblés (qui recevront des EPI et bénéficieront d’une réduction des taux d’infection) ; iv) les groupes vulnérables et marginalisés ; et v) les cas positifs qui sont gravement touchés par la maladie. Les bénéficiaires indirects seront les populations des 8 pays voisins (Afrique subsaharienne et monde arabe).
