description_narrative: PALM CORPS together with the consortium members Vision for Humanity and People empowering people  will implement COVID-19 Project with the following activities:Result 0.0 Startup and closeout activitiesA0.1: Conduct stakeholder inception meetingThe Consortiumpartners will organize an inception meeting to introduce the project to stakeholders and secure their feedback to improve final implementation strategies. The district COVID-19 task force will participate at district level since meetings involving many people areprohibited. The same meetings will be cascaded to 2 sub counties of Odupi and Uriama with the respective Sub County COVID-19 task Force.A0.2: Organize consortium Coordination meetingsThe Consortium partners will conduct three monthly partnership coordination meetings. The meetings will be held to share progress and review plans for subsequent months. The meetings will be held in partner offices on rotational basis with clear compliance with social distancing requirements.A0.3: Conduct joint monitoring field visitsAlthough all public and privately owned passenger vehicles are prohibited, PALM Corps received official taskforce movement stickers for two cars. This will enable the partners to conduct targeted field visits toselected households, VHTs, selected markets, kitchen gardens to monitor progress. The reports will be shared in the district task force coordination meetings.A0.4: Attend COVID-19 Task force coordination meetings.The consortium partners will attenddistrict and sub county covid-19 task force meetings to share progress and review project performance.A0.5: Organize end of project meetingThe project will organize a project close-out meeting thatwill involve district and sub county covid-19 taskforce and some selected beneficiaries to disseminate results and share the lessons learnt as detailing the unexpected benefits and impacts.Results 1: Community level surveillance on COVID-19 response strengthened.The project hopes to establish an effective surveillance system to detect and manage suspected cases effectively without stigmatizing the suspects or creating conflict in the community. The specific activities are:Activity 1.1: Train VHTs, LCs <(>&<)> RWCs  onCOVID 19 response.VHTs, LCs andRWCs are front-liners in COVID 19 response. The project will collaborate with the task force to train the VHTs, LCs and RWCs on COVID-19 preparedness, risk mapping and response actions in line with MOH SOPs and Protocols. This willbe a maximum of three-hourtraining sessions with 10 participants per session. In total five sessions will be held in three days to equip them to detect and report suspected cases for further investigation, distribute hand-washing facilities to targeted households, markets andhealth centres.Activity 1.2: Conduct COVID-19 risk mapping.This will be a basic data collection process on risky behaviors, hotspots, new arrivals, community suspected cases, etc. The project will provide VHTs with case definition tools and referral forms to enable reporting to health facilities for immediate action. Suspected cases will be documented and handled according to COVID-19 response protocol.Activity 1.3: Procure and provide assorted items to COVID-19 task force for surveillance.The project will provide one-off support in form of fuel, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and assorted sanitary items to facilitate district and sub county COVID-19 task force.Result 2: Enhanced communication and social mobilization capacity to respond tothe COVID-19 pandemicThe result will be achieved through community engagement, social and behavior change communication practices. The specific activities are as below:Activity 2.1: Translate/Print and disseminate MOH approved IEC materials.Visualcharts will be translated in Arabic (and local dialect of the refugees) to bring on board the refugee population that may not be able to understand English. Thesewill be distributed and disseminated by VHTs accordingly.Activity 2.2: Installsign post with posters about COVID-19 control.Theproject will erect 3 signboards at the 3 food markets in Rhino camp. The will bear messages and illustrations on COVID-19 in the commonly spoken local languages. The content will be derived from the approved MOHmaterials.Activity 2.3: Conduct community perception trackingThe project will develop text, audio and video of community perception tracking tool (CPT) through which community rumors, beliefs, ideas, concerns etc. are collected, presented todistrictCOVID-19 task force for discussion and response plan. This will ensure the task force develop a context specific behavior change strategy.Activity 2.4: Conduct radio talk shows and spot messages in language on COVID-19 pandemic.The projectwill support(district task force) to undertake radio talk shows, spots messages in the languages about COVID-19, preventive measures including hand washing, hygiene and social distancing practices to promote behavior change among the targeted communities. Advocacy sessions will be aired on radios to engage communities against gender based violence (domestic violence) and Governments on facilitating access to Reproductive Health services and commodities for women and adolescents during the fight against COVID-19pandemic.Activity 2.5: Procure and distribute communication tools and equipmentThe project will procure and distribute communication tools like megaphones and mobile phones for VHT coordinators and in addition profile district and sub county task force mobile phone contact inventory and share with VHTs and community leadership for risk communication and community engagement/feedback.Result 3: Strengthened WASH campaigns in food markets (Ofua 3, Yelulu and Siripi)To achieve the result,the projectwillempower market management committee to establish, manage and enforce hand washing at the market. The specific activities are:Activity 3.1. Procure and distribute WASH materials to targeted food markets in the refugee settlement.Theproject willprocure and distribute WASH materials including liquid and bar soap and hand washing tanks with to sustain hand washing practice at food markets places, water points and food distribution points. The WASH materials will be managed by market managementcommittees(MMC).Activity 3.2. Conduct market based WASH awareness campaigns on COVID-19 in three food markets.The awareness campaigns will be a social and behavior change approaches. Based on the social risks in Rhino Camp refugee settlement, the project willcollaborate with Health Assistants and VHT coordinators to conduct WASH awareness on market days in at three markets of Siripi, Ofua 3, and Yelulu to promote hygiene and hand washing practices.Result 4: Enhanced safety nets (Social protection)for selected vulnerable households.Two strategies will be used to achieve this result; first the project will work with the three groups supported earlier under HRGF I to support kitchen gardening to improve access to micro-nutrient richvegetablesto build enhance immunity of the households. Nutrition education including cooking demonstration will be conducted to ensure nutritive value is maintained. Secondly, the most vulnerablewomen will be identified and supported with soap and salt.   The specific activities are:Activity 4.1: Train in Kitchen/ Back Yard Gardening (BYG).The vulnerable population (PSNs) in Rhino Camp refugee settlement, like elsewhere are predicting hard times with the looming food crisis as a result of COVID-19 crisis. The projectwillpromote backyard gardening in every household to grow quick growing and nutritious vegetables to complement diet. The extension support will be offered directly in mini groups of 3-5 farmers but also remotely to minimize congregating farmers in groups.Activity 4.2: Procure and distribute agro-inputsThe project will provide one-off assorted inputs both food and commercial crops.  Vegetable seeds (nutrition pack) will be provided for targeted householdto complement diet forboth the rainy and dry season.Activity 4.3: Conduct nutrition educationThe project will provide basic nutrition education (balanced diet, food hygiene, preparation and preservation). PALM Corps has already developed a standard chart on nutrition education tailoredaccordingtofood needs for different social groups (children, pregnant and lactating mothers, the sick and elderly).Activity 4.4: Provide hand washing soap and salt to selected vulnerable households using Cash Transfer Programming.The project willidentify 140 women and girls, elderly, disabled people and provide vouchers to enable access to 2 bars soap and two sachets of salt for three month in accordance with the minimum expenditure basket (MEB) principle. The price of salt had increased by 300%at the onset of COVID-19.

title_narrative: Niger - COVID-19 Support Programme in G5 Sahel Countries - Burkina Faso, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Chad (PARC COVID-19 - G5 Sahel)
Niger - Programme d'appui en réponse à la crise de la COVID-19 dans les pays du G5 Sahel - Burkina Faso, Mali, Mauritanie, Niger, Tchad - (PARC COVID-19 - G5 Sahel)
description_narrative: The proposed intervention concerns the Niger component of the COVID-19 Crisis Response Programme in the G5 Sahel Countries (PARC COVID-19 – G5 SAHEL). This is a loan and award a grant to the G5 Sahel countries (Burkina Faso, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Chad) of UA 118.9 million and UA 89.6 million respectively from the COVID-19 Rapid Response Facility. It will be implemented over 12 months from July 2020. The Programme was appraised in April 2020 following requests to the Bank by the countries. Niger recorded its first case of COVID-19 on 19 March 2020. As of 5 June 2020, the country had 1461 cases, the number of which has been rising steadily in the last few days. To curb the spread of the COVID19 pandemic, the country has taken several preventive and protective measures, including: (i) a nationwide ban on gatherings; (ii) the closure of all land borders, except for the transportation of goods; (iii) the suspension of public land transport; and (iv) the imposition of a curfew in Niamey. These measures have led to a drastic contraction of supply and demand, resulting in a sudden downturn in Niger’s economy. This Programme complements the other budget support operations, particularly the Multinational Coronavirus Pandemic Control Support Project for G5 member countries approved on 9 June 2020, aimed at providing the region with adequate operational capacities to combat the pandemic. More specifically, the programme will contribute to the financing of response plans through the budget support it will provide. It will also support measures aimed at improving the financial management of the response plans and mitigating the health, social and economic-related impacts.

La présente intervention concerne la composante nigérienne du Programme d’appui en réponse à la crise de la COVID-19 dans les pays du G5 sahel (PARC COVID-19 – G5 SAHEL). Il s'agit d'une opération de prêt et don aux pays du G5 Sahel (Burkina Faso, Mali, Mauritanie, Niger, Tchad) respectivement de 118,9 millions d’UC et 89,6 millions d’UC de la Facilité de réponse rapide à la COVID-19. Elle sera mise en œuvre sur une période de 12 mois à partir de juillet 2020. Le programme a été évalué en avril 2020, à la suite des demandes adressées par les pays à la Banque. Le Niger a enregistré son premier cas de personne infectée par la COVID-19 le 19 mars 2020. Au 5 juin 2020, le pays enregistrait 1461 cas, en progression soutenue au cours des derniers jours. Pour contenir la propagation de la pandémie de la COVID-19, le pays a pris plusieurs mesures de prévention et de protection comme : (i) l’interdiction sur toute l’étendue du territoire national des rassemblements ; (ii) la fermeture de toutes les frontières terrestres, excepté pour le transport des marchandises ; (iii) la suspension des transports terrestres en commun ; et (iv) l’instauration à Niamey d’un couvre-feu. Ces mesures ont engendré une forte contraction de l’offre et de la demande économiques, conduisant ainsi à un brusque ralentissement général de l’économie nigérienne. Le Programme vient en complément des autres appuis de la Banque, notamment le Projet multinational d’appui en faveur des pays membres du G5 sahel pour la lutte contre la pandémie a coronavirus approuvé le 9 juin 2020, qui vise à doter la région de capacités opérationnelles pour faire face à la pandémie. De manière spécifique, le Programme contribuera au financement des plans de riposte grâce aux aides budgétaires qu’il apporte. Il soutiendra également des mesures visant une meilleure gestion financière des plans de riposte, et une atténuation des impacts de la pandémie au plan sanitaire, social et économique.

The overall objective of this programme is to contribute to mitigating the health, social and economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in Niger. Its specific objectives are to: (i) build the capacity of the health system to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic; (ii) mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on vulnerable people; and (iii) mitigate the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Le programme a pour objectif global de contribuer à l’atténuation de l’incidence de la pandémie de la COVID-19 sur le plan sanitaire, social et économique au Niger. Il vise spécifiquement : (i) le renforcement des capacités sanitaires de lutte contre la pandémie de la COVID-19 ; (ii) l’atténuation de l’incidence sur les personnes vulnérables de la pandémie de la COVID-19 ; et (iii) l’atténuation de l’incidence économique de la pandémie de la COVID-19.

The entire population of Niger will benefit from this programme which will help to mitigate the health and socio-economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on the population, especially the most vulnerable segments, including women. It will also contribute to reducing the economic shock on local enterprises (including SMEs run by women) affected by the sharp economic downturn resulting from the pandemic. The programme will also make it possible to build the capacity of Niger’s public administration in health response, protection of the most vulnerable segments of the population and support to economic activities. All these elements will contribute to strengthening the resilience of Niger’s economy and reducing the country’s fragility factors.

Toute la population nigérienne bénéficiera du présent programme. Il permettra d’atténuer les impacts sanitaires et socio-économiques de la pandémie de la COVID-19 sur la population, et notamment les plus vulnérables, y compris les femmes. Il contribuera également à réduire le choc économique sur les entreprises nationales (y compris les PME dirigées par des femmes) victimes du fort ralentissement de l’économie résultant de la pandémie en cours. Par ailleurs, grâce à ce programme, les capacités de l’administration publique nigérienne seront renforcées en matière de riposte sanitaire, de protection des couches les plus vulnérables de la population et de soutien à l’activité économique. Tous ces éléments contribueront à renforcer la résilience de l’économie nigérienne et à réduire les facteurs de fragilité du pays.

title_narrative: Uganda - Covid-19 Crisis Response Budget Support Program (CRSP)
Ouganda - Programme d’appui en Réponse à la Crise du Covid-19 (PARC)
description_narrative: The COVID-19 Crisis Response Support Program (CRSP) to Uganda is designed as budget support within the framework of the Bank Group’s COVID-19 Crisis Response Facility. Uganda confirmed its first case of COVID-19 on 21 March 2020. This number had increased to 1,075 confirmed cases on July 22. The country’s overburdened health system does not have adequate resources to face this health emergency. Uganda is currently facing an additional challenge of a deadly invasion of desert locusts, which is posing a threat to food security and exacerbating the country’s vulnerability during this pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic has hit the Ugandan economy hard, both directly and indirectly, through global, regional and domestic transmission channels, with the hospitality, tourism, trading and manufacturing industries particularly badly affected. The Government has responded to the crisis with a broad financial package aimed at tackling the COVID-19 health emergency and supporting economic activity. It allocated resources to the health sector, expand social safety net programs, and provide targeted support to the impacted economic sectors. The program, which results from a request of the Government dated April 9th, 2020, was appraised on 15-30 April 2020, and will be applied for a period of one year (2020/2021). Bank support, estimated at UA 23 million, will provide financing to the budget for targeted spending, aimed at containing and mitigating the health and economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Le Programme d’appui en réponse à la crise du COVID-19 (PARC) en Ouganda se présente sous forme d’appui budgétaire en réponse à la crise (ARBC) en conformité avec la Facilité de réponse rapide à la COVID-19 (CRF) du Groupe de la Banque. L’Ouganda a confirmé son premier cas de Covid-19 le 21 mars 2020. Au 22 juillet 2020, le nombre de personnes atteintes du coronavirus était de 1 075 cas confirmés. Le système de santé surchargé du pays ne dispose pas de ressources suffisantes pour faire face à cette urgence sanitaire. L’Ouganda est, en outre, actuellement confronté à un défi supplémentaire, celui d’une invasion de criquets pèlerins, qui constitue une menace pour la sécurité alimentaire et exacerbe la vulnérabilité du pays durant cette pandémie. La pandémie de Covid-19 a durement frappé l’économie ougandaise, de façon directe et indirecte, à travers la baisse des flux de transmission mondiaux, régionaux et nationaux. Elle a notamment affecté particulièrement les secteurs de l’hôtellerie, du tourisme, du commerce et de la fabrication. Le gouvernement a réagi à la crise par un vaste programme financier visant à s’attaquer à l’urgence sanitaire imposée par le Covid-19 et à soutenir l’activité économique. Il a affecté des ressources au secteur de la santé, a élargi les programmes de protection sociale et a apporté un soutien ciblé aux secteurs économiques touchés. Faisant suite à la demande formulée par le gouvernement en date du 9 avril 2020, le programme a été évalué du 15 au 30 avril 2020 et se déroulera sur une période d’un an (2020/2021). Le soutien de la Banque, estimé à 23 millions d’UC, sera mis en œuvre par un financement budgétaire de dépenses ciblées, visant à contenir et à atténuer l’impact sanitaire et économique de la pandémie du Covid-19.

The goal of the proposed operation is to support Uganda’s National COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Plan to strengthen the COVID-19 outbreak response mechanisms and mitigate the social and economic impacts of the pandemic. The proposed operation seeks to achieve three short-term and medium-term outcomes: (i) enhanced capacity to test and treat COVID-19 patients to reduce risk of infection and morbidity; (ii) ease impact of the lockdown, and other COVID-19 related measures, on the poorest; and (iii) mitigate risk to medium-term macroeconomic stabilization and economic resilience.

Le programme a pour objectif de soutenir le Plan national de préparation et de riposte à la COVID-19 pour renforcer les mécanismes d’action et atténuer les effets économiques et sociaux de la pandémie. L’opération cible trois effets à court et moyen terme : i) capacité accrue de test et de traitement des patients atteints de COVID-19 afin de réduire le risque d’infection et de morbidité ; ii) effets amoindris du confinement et d’autres mesures de lutte contre la pandémie sur les plus pauvres ; et iii) risque atténué pour la stabilisation macroéconomique et la résilience économique à moyen terme.

The program will benefit the poor and vulnerable through rapid diagnosis, isolation and management of infected persons, strengthened livelihoods and expanded social protection coverage which includes vulnerable households and the urban poor. The program will also benefit households, private sector, financial sector actors through a faster and more inclusive economic recovery on the back of a more resilient businesses and workforce.

Le programme profitera aux pauvres et aux personnes vulnérables grâce au diagnostic rapide, à l’isolement et à la prise en charge des personnes infectées, au renforcement des moyens de subsistance et à l’élargissement de la couverture de protection sociale aux ménages vulnérables et aux pauvres des zones urbaines. Il sera également bénéfique pour les ménages, le secteur privé et les acteurs du secteur financier grâce à une reprise économique plus rapide et plus inclusive, soutenue par des entreprises et une main-d’œuvre plus résiliente.

description_narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19Purpose
The purpose of the contribution is to support the implementation of the continental Covid-19 strategy "Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak". The strategy was adopted by the African Union (all Africa's 55 health ministers/health ministries) on February 22, 2020 during a crisis meeting. The strategy has two overarching goals: to prevent severe disease and death from Covid-19 infection in member states and to minimize the social and economic consequences of the Covid-19 outbreak.

An Addendum to the strategy has also been developed, the AU COVID-19 Pandemic Preparedness and Response Plan Addendum to the African Union COVID-19 Continental Strategy, which includes specific reference to ensure access to basic health care, including maternal and child health care during the Covid-19 pandemic.

Henceforth, it should be noted that the reference to strategy includes both the Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak” and its Addendum. The strategy includes the following pillars: Coordination and Collaboration; Surveillance; Laboratory; Countermeasures; Healthcare Preparedness; Risk Communication and Social Engagement; Supply Chain Management; Special Populations, Settings, and Policies; and Science, Standards and Regulations.

Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a specialized agency of the African Union. Africa CDC has been tasked by the African Union to implement the strategy.

Sida intends to support the Africa CDC with 20 million SEK to implement the pillars focused on Coordination and Collaboration and Risk Communication and Social Engagement.

This has been determined in consultation with the EU and other member states that constitute Team Europe, which includes Sweden. The arrangement means that the EU and the member states (Spain, Sweden, Germany and Austria) are coordinated through a joint budget and work plan and joint reporting (both narrative and financial, including audit). Team Europe's total support amounts to EUR 25.85 million (includes SEK 20 million from Sida). Attached document “Joint planning and reporting arrangements for Team Europe support to ACDC” sets out all relevant details. However, it should be noted that Sweden will enter into a bilateral/separate agreement with Africa CDC.

Sida will contribute to Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak and its Addendum through two other contributions: WHO-AFRO (SEK 30 million) and Together4SRHR (SEK 30 million through an amendment to the agreement). Sida views the contributions as three parts of a coherent support in line with the above strategy, and comprises a total of SEK 80 million.

The strategy is implemented through the Africa Task Force for Coronavirus (AFTCOR), where Africa CDC, UN and AU member countries lead working groups, and through Africa CDC's Incident Management System (IMS). A number of partners, both UN and non-state actors, also contribute to the implementation of the strategy.

These implementing partners are financed either directly by aid donors who finance supplementary efforts, or via Africa CDC, which then transfers funds to implementing partners.

Context
The reason that the contribution (without an explicit focus on SRHR) is funded by the regional SRHR strategy is because of the expected consequences of COVID-19. These are anticipated to be dramatic and all-encompassing regarding the development spectrum – encompassing e.g., social and economic aspects. 

Africa CDC reports that with regards to its member states that there on 25 June 2020 was: 337,315 cases; and 8,863 deaths. Clearly, it is important to note that these are only reported/confirmed cases and that numbers rapidly increase daily. 

Despite the various measures in place, the virus is likely to spread further and likely to continue to have significant impacts on e.g., the economy and livelihoods of the populations of the African continent. The social, health and development impacts of the pandemic on the continent are currently devastating and could signify a reversal of the development gains of the previous decades - there are already evidence that point to this direction.

The World Bank estimates that Sub-Saharan African economies could lose between USD 37 to USD 79 billion in 2020 due to consequences of COVID-19. Economic growth could contract from 2.4% in 2019 to -5.1% in 2020, bringing about the first recession in 25 years. 

Sida notes that a challenge attached to the contribution could be longer term institutional strengthening and sustainability given that the focus and purpose is intertwined with COVID-19 and its trajectory. The agreement will cover a one year implementation period and entail a one-off disbursement. Nonetheless, there are reasons to assume that there will rippling effects and that the contribution will help also to strengthen Africa’s national public health institutions’ capacities to reduce the overall disease burden on the continent – beyond the COVID-19 pandemic. The issue of sustainability will be an ongoing dialogue issue between Sweden, Africa CDC, the EU and other relevant stakeholders. 

Sida recognizes that the work of Africa CDC is crucial as health is a development issue that affects the economic, social and security concerns of countries and regions. This is especially apparent when infections or epidemics occur as became apparent during the Ebola outbreak in West Africa in 2014/2015 and again during the current COVID-19 pandemic.

Sida also takes note of the precarious situation on the African continent, which currently faces the burden of communicable and non-communicable diseases (NCDs), and injury and trauma. This is combined with fragile health systems and inadequate water, sanitation and hygiene infrastructure, population mobility that will make key preventing measures such as physical distancing very difficult to uphold, and contribute to increase susceptibility for unrest.

Challenges resulting from several infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, TB and malaria), maternal mortality as well as outbreaks such as yellow fever, cholera and natural disasters (as a result of climate change and conflict), still affect the continent adversely and continue to pose serious threats alongside the current COVID-19 pandemic, which will likely cause widespread illness and death in Africa (according to Africa CDC). One factor that could mitigate deaths in Africa is demography; more than 50 percent of the population is under 20 years old, a group that has been relatively spared from illness and death from COVID-19 across the world.

Overall with regards to health security, the Ebola crisis in 2014-2015 highlighted the unpreparedness of health systems in Africa. It was then made clear that health systems in Africa are unable to adequately cope with major health crises. Urgent and collective action is now needed to protect the African region from the health security threat that the COVID-19 pandemic poses.

It is clear that capacity gaps are due to insufficient resources (financial, human, and logistics) and fragmented services. Furthermore, limited community engagement, weak health systems, inadequate inter-country collaborations, and limited effective partnerships.

Across the world, African countries are least prepared for epidemics or pandemics. All African countries lack foundational health systems capacities for vital epidemic and pandemic response and national health security is fundamentally weak across the African continent. There are also severe weaknesses in countries’ abilities to prevent, detect, and respond to health emergencies; vulnerabilities to political, socioeconomic, and environmental risks that can confound outbreak preparedness and response; and, a lack of adherence to international norms.

Africa CDC acts now to support African countries to address these gaps through coordination and to strengthen preparedness and response through partnerships.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19Syfte
Insatsens syfte är att stödja implementeringen av den kontinentala covid-19 strategin ”Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak”. Strategin antogs av den Afrikanska Unionen (alla Afrikas 55 hälsoministrar/hälsoministerier) 22 februari 2020 under ett krismöte. Strategin har två övergripande mål: att förebygga svår sjukdom och död av Covid-19 infektion i medlemsländer och att minimera sociala och ekonomiska konsekvenser av covid-19 utbrottet.

Ett tillägg finns även till strategin, AU COVID-19 Pandemic Preparedness and Response Plan Addendum to the African Union COVID-19 Continental Strategy, som inkluderar specifik referens till att säkerställa tillgång till grundläggande hälsosjukvård, inklusive mödrabarnhälsovård under covid-19 pandemin.

Med strategin menas hädanefter både Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak och dess Addendum. 

Strategin omfattar följande pelare: Coordination and Collaboration; Surveillance; Laboratory; Countermeasures; Healthcare Preparedness; Risk Communication and Social Engagement; Supply Chain Management; Special Populations, Settings, and Policies; och Science, Standards and Regulations. 

Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) är en institution som tillhör den Afrikanska Unionen. Africa CDC har av den Afrikanska Unionen fått uppdraget att implementera strategin. 

Sida avser att stödja Africa CDC med 20 miljoner SEK för implementerandet av pelare fokuserade på Coordination and Collaboration och Risk Communication and Social Engagement. 

Detta har bestämts i samråd med EU och andra medlemsstater som utgör Team Europe där Sverige ingår. Upplägget innebär at EU och medlemsstaterna (Spanien, Sverige, Tyskland och Österrike) är samordnade under en gemensam budget och arbetsplan och gemensam rapportering (både narrativ och finansiell, inklusive revision). Team Europes totala stöd utgör EUR 25,85 miljoner (inkluderar 20 miljoner SEK från Sida). Bilagt dokument “Joint planning and reporting arrangements for Team Europe support to ACDC” redogör för alla relevanta detaljer. Det bör dock noteras att Sverige kommer att ingå ett bilateralt/separat avtal med Kommissionen för den Afrikanska Unionen. 

Sida kommer att bidra till Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak och dess Addendum genom två andra insatser WHO-AFRO (30 miljoner SEK) och Together4SRHR (30 miljoner SEK genom en avtalsändring). Sida ser på insatserna som tre delar av ett sammanhållet stöd i linje med ovan nämnda strategi, och omfattar totalt 80 miljoner SEK. 

Den kontinentala COVID-19 strategin implementeras genom Africa Task Force for Coronavirus (AFTCOR), där Africa CDC, FN och AU:s medlemsländer leder arbetsgrupper, och genom Africa CDC’s Incident Management System (IMS). Ett antal partners, både FN och ickestatliga aktörer, bidrar också till att implementera strategin.

Dessa implementerande partners finansieras antingen direkt av biståndsgivare som finansierar kompletterande insatser, eller via Africa CDC som sedan vidareförmedlar medel till implementerande partners. 

Kontext
Anledningen till att insatsen (utan ett uttryckligt fokus på SRHR) finansieras av den regionala SRHR-strategin är på grund av de förväntade konsekvenserna av COVID-19. Dessa förväntas vara dramatiska och allomfattande vad gäller utvecklingsspektrumet - som t.ex. omfattar sociala och ekonomiska aspekter, och COIVD-19 riskerar att tränga undan annan grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård, inklusive tjänster för sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa.

Africa CDC rapporterar att det bland sina medlemsländer, den 25 juni 2020 ,fanns: 337 315 bekräftade fall av Covid-19; och 8 863 bekräftade dödsfall till följd av Covid-19. Det bör noteras att dessa endast avser rapporterade/bekräftad fall och att antalet snabbt ökar dagligen.

Trots att olika åtgärder har vidtagits kommer viruset enligt olika beräkningar att spridas ytterligare och fortsätta att ha betydande effekter på t.ex. ekonomin och livsmedelsförsörjningen på den afrikanska kontinenten. De sociala, hälso- och utvecklingseffekterna av pandemin på kontinenten är för närvarande förödande och kan innebära att utvecklingsvinningar under de senaste decennierna urholkas. Det finns redan bevis som pekar på denna riktning.

Världsbanken uppskattar att de afrikanska ekonomierna söder om Sahara kan förlora mellan 37 och 79 miljarder USD under år 2020 till följd av Covid-19 konsekvenser. Den ekonomiska tillväxten kan minska från 2,4% 2019 till -5,1% 2020, vilket skulle leda till den första lågkonjunkturen på 25 år.

Sida konstaterar att en utmaning kopplad till insatsen kan vara långsiktigt institutionellt stärkande och hållbarhet med tanke på att fokus och syfte är sammanflätade med Covid-19 och dess utveckling.

Avtalet täcker en implementeringsperiod på ett år och innebär en engångsutbetalning. Det finns emellertid skäl att anta att insatsen kommer att ha bredare effekter och att insatsen också kommer att bidra till att stärka Afrikas nationella folkhälsoinstitutioners kapacitet för att minska den totala sjukdomsbördan på kontinenten bortom Covid-19-pandemin. Hållbarhet kommer att vara en pågående dialogfråga mellan Sverige, Africa CDC, EU och andra relevanta aktörer.

Sida anser att Africa CDC:s arbete är mycket viktigt eftersom hälsa är en utvecklingsfråga som påverkar de ekonomiska, sociala och säkerhetsmässiga aspekterna i länder och regioner. Detta är särskilt uppenbart när det gäller infektioner eller epidemier. Detta visade sig under Ebola-utbrottet i Västafrika 2014/2015 och återigen under den nuvarande COVID-19-pandemi.

Sida noterar också den osäkra situationen på den afrikanska kontinenten, som för närvarande står inför bördan av smittsamma och icke-smittsamma sjukdomar, skador och trauma. Detta kombineras med bräckliga hälsosystem och otillräcklig infrastruktur för vatten, sanitet och hygien och stor befolkningsrörlighet. Detta kommer att göra viktiga förebyggande åtgärder som fysisk distansering mycket svåra att upprätthålla och öka risken för oroligheter.

Utmaningar till följd av flera infektionssjukdomar (t.ex. HIV, TB och malaria), mödradödlighet samt utbrott som gulafeber, kolera och naturkatastrofer (som ett resultat av klimatförändringar och konflikter), påverkar fortfarande kontinenten negativt och fortsätter att utgöra allvarliga hot tillsammans med den nuvarande Covid-19 pandemin, som sannolikt kommer att orsaka utbredd sjukdom och död i Afrika (enligt Africa CDC). En faktor som kan mildra dödsfall i Afrika är demografi; mer än 50 procent av befolkningen är under 20 år gammal, en grupp som över hela världen har relativt förskonats från sjukdom och död till följd av Covid-19. 

Övergripande när det gäller hälsosäkerhet visade Ebolakrisen 2014–2015 att hälsosystem i Afrika inte kan hantera stora hälsokriser på ett tillfredsställande sätt. Brådskande och kollektiva åtgärder behövs nu för att skydda den afrikanska regionen från det hälsohot som Covid-19-pandemin utgör.

Det är uppenbart att kapacitetsbrister beror på otillräckliga resurser (ekonomiska, mänskliga och logistiska) och fragmenterade tjänster. Dessutom finns andra stora utmaningar, t.ex. begränsat samhällsengagemang, svaga hälsosystem, otillräckliga samarbeten mellan länder och begränsade effektiva partnerskap.

Över hela världen är afrikanska länder minst förberedda på att hantera epidemier eller pandemier. I alla afrikanska länder saknas grundläggande kapacitet bland hälsosystem för att effektivt bekämpa epidemier och pandemier. Det finns även allvarliga brister i ländernas förmåga att förebygga, upptäcka och bemöta hälsohot; hög utsatthet för politiska, socioekonomiska och miljömässiga risker som kan försvåra beredskap och hanterandet av utbrott; och bristande efterlevnad av internationella normer.

Africa CDC agerar nu för att stödja afrikanska länder att hantera dessa brister genom att samordna, och stärka beredskap och respons genom partnerskap.

The first and foremost purpose of the intended contribution is to enable Africa CDC to promptly and systematically implement “The Africa Joint Continental Strategy for COVID-19 Outbreak”, endorsed by the AU. The articulated goals of the strategy are to: prevent severe morbidity and mortality from COVID-19 infection in African Union (AU) member states; and, to minimize social disruption and economic consequences of COVID-19 outbreaks.
The strategy has two objectives: coordinate efforts of AU member states, AU agencies, WHO, and other partners and stakeholder to ensure synergy and minimize duplication; and, promote evidence-based public health practice for surveillance, prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and control of COVID-19.
Consequently, beyond the pressing need to ensure 1) effective coordination and collaboration, the strategy (and the addendum - i.e., implementation plan) stipulates that efforts will be dedicated to:
2) Surveillance: Collect, analyze, and disseminate accurate, timely data about the epidemiology of COVID-19.
3) Laboratory: Ensure quality-assured testing for COVID-19 diagnosis, genotyping, and special studies.
4) Countermeasures: Support implementation of evidence-based interventions at individual and population-level to reduce COVID-19 transmission.
5) Healthcare preparedness: Strengthen capacity of healthcare facilities to manage surge in patient visits and to effectively identify, isolate, and manage people with COVID-19 infection.
6) Risk communication and social engagement: Provide guidance that is clear, comprehensible, evidence based, culturally appropriate, and adapted to special populations and circumstances.
7) Supply chain management: Establish and maintain supply chains for shared resources, including personal protective equipment, laboratory supplies and equipment, and, if available and necessary, medical countermeasures.
8) Special populations, settings, and policies: Assess and manage issues related to special populations (e.g., refugees, internally displaced persons), analyze and guide on ethical and legal issues (e.g., quarantine, healthcare triage, travel, trade), and develop plans for continuity of essential public health operations (e.g., maternal child health programs, immunizations).
9) Science, standards and regulations: Ensure that timelyand coordinated scientific and policy information is made available to decision makers within AU member states.
The Sida funds will be dedicated to pillar 1) effective coordination and collaboration and pillar 6) risk communication and social engagement.
In terms of specific results, the Swedish contribution will primarily contribute to: 
-A more effectively functioning Africa CDC, including improved functions in regional coordination, epi analysis, and partnership development.
-Reductions in disease spread in countries where community health workers were deployed due to more effective public health behaviors (e.g., physical distancing, mask wearing, hand washing etc.). 
This has been agreed with the EU and other member states, who will fund other pillars and results - all in a harmonized approach. Through the Team Europe, also the following results will be achieved (to be funded by other members):
- Improvements in healthcare outcomes (e.g., lower spread of cases and less severe cases) in IDP and refugee camp settings. 
- Improved member state capacity in surveillance and detection through technical experts, trainings, and community health workers. 
- Increase in testing rates in countries where lab supplies are distributed. 
- Improvements in testing, tracing and treatment outcomes in countries where community health workers and rapid responders are deployed. 
The joint Team Europe work plan and budget outlines what the EU as an entity and each EU member state will fund, and should thus be consulted for details.
It should be noted that the Swedish contribution has also been harmonized with the support to WHO-AFRO and the Together4SRHR platform and is in line with the relevant Swedish strategy for the regional SRHR team (see the appraisal plan regarding details pertaining to the 2 relevant Swedish government strategies).

title_narrative: Improving access to quality of care for COVID-19 in 11 States of Sudan.
description_narrative:
On 30 January, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the 2019 coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) for countries to prepare and respond to it in time. Afterwards, on 11 March 2020, WHO declared COVID-19 a global pandemic as it spreads to many countries. Globally, as of 10:00am CEST, 01 May 2020, a total of 3,175, 207 confirmed cases of COVID-19, including 224, 172 deaths (CFR% 7.06%) have been reported to WHO from 215 countries, areas or territories. In the Sudan, according to the Federal Ministry of Health (FMOH), 91 new confirmed cases and associated 5 deaths of COVID-19 were reported on 01 May 2020 increasing the total number of confirmed cases to 533 with 36 associated deaths (CFR: 6.7 %) and 42 recovered cases. Majority of the confirmed cases (474 89%) are from Khartoum State  followed by Gezira (24 cases), Sinnar (8 case), North Kordofan (8 cases), River Nile (5 case), Gedaref (5 cases) and West Kordofan (2 cases). The government of Sudan has been implementing various “lock downs” to slow COVID-19 transmission by limiting contact between people. 

The WHO has defined four transmission scenarios for COVID-19 and advised each country to assess its risk and rapidly implement the necessary measures at the appropriate scale at national and sub-national level as there is no one-size-fits-all. Accordingly, WHO classified the current transmission scenario in Sudan as “sporadic” as cases are either imported or locally detected. The WHO recommended that countries must do everything they can to stop cases from becoming clusters and clusters from becoming explosive outbreaks. As hitherto experiences attested, majority (80%) of COVID-19 patients developed into mild and moderate disease. Only 15% develops sever diseases while only 5% develops critical diseases requiring in patient care or Intensive Care Units (ICU) at designated isolation centres. Confirmed COVID-19 cases should be isolated in dedicated facilities to prevent transmission and optimize clinical care.  Rapid expansion of clinical care capacity to manage COVID-19 cases requires substantial reconfiguring of existing health facilities and repurposing existing health facilities to provide essential life-saving services. In Sudan, only 14 out of 46 (30%) designated COVID-19 isolation facilities in 14 States are functioning with a total capacity of 641 normal beds, 69 ICU beds and 53 ventilators as at 30 April 2020. Recent assessments by WHO revealed that there are huge gaps in the designated isolation centres prepared for management of COVID-19 cases in Sudan. Among other things, isolation centres and treatment facilities lack appropriate equipment, medicines, medical supplies and WASH facilities in most instances. The need for operational support to functional isolation centres was reported in many occasions. 

Although there were no suspected or confirmed COVID-19 cases reported from the two-areas, it is a matter of time, since all the three countries neighboring them (South Sudan, Ethiopia and Sudan) already reported confirmed  COVID-19 cases and their transmission scenarios are fast progressing. Preventing importation of cases in underserved and marginalized communities such as the newly accessed two areas in South Kordofan and Blue Nile state is both critical and human-right issue. Such areas could serve as amplifiers of the pandemic becoming clusters of cases without timely intervention. Therefore, the two-areas are at greater risk of importation and local spread of COVID-19 without timely interventions. 

This project is going to complement ongoing government, UN agencies and NGOs response effort under the auspices of the Country Preparedness and Response Plan (CPRP) to COVID-19. As WHO, this proposal will focus on addressing the three pillars of interventions (i.e. risk communication, IPC and case management) identified as critical gaps by the allocation paper in 11 prioritized States of Suda
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: WASH response to COVID-19 for the most vulnerable malnourished children and their community at both nutrition center and household levels.
description_narrative:
The proposed action’s objective is to strengthen awareness and implementation of optimal COVID19-specific and general hygiene practices in local communities and health facilities at-risk or affected by COVID19 in order to contain on-going COVID19 outbreak in the targeted areas of Ghor Province.

In the already fragile country of Afghanistan with a “current coverage of WASH services including water supply infrastructure, sanitation facilities and hygiene promotion supplies already unable to adequately support basic WASH needs from conflict and natural disasters” according to the COVID19 Multi-sector Humanitarian Country Plan, the additional burden of a country-wide disease outbreak could have disastrous consequences. The first confirmed case in Afghanistan has been reported by MoPH on February 24th, in Herat province. Since then, additional provinces have been infected, with now 20 out of 34 provinces experiencing confirmed cases with a total of 484 confirmed cases according to OCHA’s last Daily Brief (9th of April). Ghor province is already particularly affected by cycles of heavy armed conflict and natural disaster like drought, heavy rain cause to flash flood and have very high needs in terms of WASH. The emergence of the COVID19 outbreak could be disastrous considering also the fragile health system in this Province.

In order to respond to the high needs identified, Action Against Hunger (AAH) will launch a WASH emergency response to the COVID19 outbreak to increase the implementation of improved hygiene practices, notably hand-washing, and, so, prevent further spread of COVID19 outbreak, both at community level and health facilities level and with a specific focus on malnourished boys and girls. This emergency response will target 58,089 persons (15,371 men, 15,998 women, 13,091 boys and 13,629 girls) and will focus on the four following districts: Ferozkoh, Shahrak, Tulak and Taiwara, of Ghor Province, that have been identified by IOM as being among the 25 districts to be prioritized for COVID19 response since they are at higher risk of being affected by COVID19 outbreak.

More specifically, the assistance will target the two following levels:
-	At community level, with a strong focus on strengthening the good hygiene knowledge and practices among local population, in particular women and girls due to the disproportionate impact of the outbreak, in order to reduce the potential contamination vectors, notably through extensive handwashing practices. But, since lack of access to hygiene items is one of the main bottleneck preventing handwashing (with lack of access to water), a focus is also needed on facilitating the access to hygiene items for the most vulnerable part of the population and/or the part of the population at higher risk of being contaminated and/or developing complicated symptoms (SAM/MAM children, women attending ANC/PNC, elderly individuals, individuals with chronic diseases, IDPs). In addition, since COVID19 is a new kind of disease differing from the disease the local communities are aware of and have been sensitized on (COVID19 is not a water-borne disease), it is also necessary to raise the awareness of local population and key community leaders regarding COVID19’s specificities.
-	At health facility level, with a strong focus on strengthening the hygiene/IPC measures and waste management systems enforced in each health facility. Doing so will allow to avoid health facilities to be become a COVID19 contamination cluster but will also allow the health facilities to continue providing lifesaving health amp nutrition services which will be even more crucial in the context of COVID19.
Based on the designed program, AAH will provide support to 23 Health facilities including Provincial Hospital and Sar-miyash Hospital. Throughout the project, the required precautionary measures from MoPH and WHO guidelines, but also COVID19 Response plan, will be taken for group activities as well as for AAH’s staff.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

This project is going to complement ongoing government, UN agencies and NGOs response effort under the auspices of the Country Preparedness and Response Plan (CPRP) to COVID-19. As WHO, this proposal will focus on addressing the three pillars of interventions (i.e. risk communication, IPC and case management) identified as critical gaps by the allocation paper in 11 prioritized States of Suda

title_narrative: NANA - Youth Eng. on prevention  Covid19
sector_narrative: The right to life and security
description_narrative: The world is currently facing a devastating scenario because of the COVID-19 pandemic, and all countries with confirmed cases are taking measures to react ranging from the lightest to the most severe to contain the transmission of the virus and protect people, especially to the most vulnerable.The Mozambican government has also expressed its concerns in this regard and have put forward structural measures aimed at reducing the risk of infection by Covid-19. One of the measures taken was the declarationof State Emergency phase 3 as of 1 - 30 of April, then extended to 1 - 31 May 2020. The declaration of a state of emergency was accompanied by other related measures aimed at blocking the chain of contagion by Covid-19, such as the restriction of the number of people in the workplace, limitation of passengers number on public transport, obligation to wear masks in crowded places, closure of entertainment places,schools at all levels, among others.The closure of schools, and social distance (includingconfinement of people at home), are in fact great measures to prevent the spread of the Covid-19 pandemic. However, in many rural communities in Mozambique, due to factorsassociated with poverty, access to information is limited. TV and the Internet isaccessible to a very limited group of people, which contributes to (i) exposure of communities to Covid-19, by ignoring disease prevention measures; (ii) Limits access to distance education for thousands of boys and (iii) girls and women may be exposed to situations of Gender Based Violence.Oxfam Mozambique designed its response strategy to COVID-19 and has been looking for potential donors to materialize its activities. The Education Program for Active Citizenship and its partners is responsible  for implementing a part of this response strategy to Covid-19, during theschool closing period, by (i) disseminating Covid-19 prevention messages, (ii) piloting, together with local education authorities,radio-schools, to guarantee the right to education inthe face of Covid-19 and (iii) support youth organizations to prevention and  raise alert for Gender Based Violence  in context of COVID 19, due to women and girls confinement and permanent exposure.Young women and men are a valuable resource and network during crises and public health emergencies. Through their informal and formal groupsand networks, they can help to break the chain of infection by working closely with their community, including the health authorities. Young people's involvement inthe COVID-19 response should be encouraged as they are drivers of change and educators in their communities and among their peers. In general, they are highly mobile, fast movers, entrepreneurs, innovators and users of various online communication and social media that can be used to mobilize people in responding to and preventing the COVID-19 pandemic.Inspired on the above, Oxfam Mozambique intends, through youth engagement, to trigger actions in order to respond to 2 components of response to COVID-19 in two districts of Zambezia province, specifically Mocuba district through our local implementing partner NANA and Nocoadala through aour Local youth implanting partner ARZ (Associação das Raparigas da Zambezia)The management of the project on the ground will be under the leadership of NANA, which will ensure the mobilization of young people to engage in community awareness campaigns to prevent Covid-19. NANA will also work in partnership with another youth organization, ARZ, to join efforts to prevent and report potential situations of gender-based violence at the community level. Relevant stakeholders such as community authorities and district services will also be involved in the implementation of this initiative to ensure ownership and continuity.
participating_org_narrative: NANA- Association for  Development Support, is a non-profit, private development legal entity with legal personality with administrative, financial and patrimonial autonomy. It gathers 32 young members of both sexes. The organization is of provincial scope, with its soothes in the City of Mocuba, street Robert Mugabe, founded the 14 of February of 1998.The NANA actions are developed in the Districts of Mocuba, Lugela and Alto Molócuè. NANA began its activities in the City of Mocuba through a nucleus of students from theMocuba Secondary School who were concerned about environmental problems. Over the last few years NANA has expanded its base of intervention, covering, in addition to the environmental area, the areas of Health, HIV / AIDS, Education, child support and protection and Good Governance. In its intervention NANA also prioritizes the interaction and capacity building of other Civil Society Organizations at the local level.NANA and its partners work to ensure that human rights are respected, protected and held as the primary responsibility of the state. The NANA has a strategic plan (2016-2021) and two statutes, one published in the Bulletin of the Republic, third series: NANA-Nucleus of Friends of Nature and Environment and another thatrepeals the first, which is in the process of itspublication where the NANA appears as a Development Support Organization, approved by the organization's General Assembly on February 14, 2013.

title_narrative: Guinea Bissau - Coronavirus Pandemic (COVID-19) Control Support Project - PALPC
Guinée Bissau - Projet d'appui à la lutte contre la pandémie à Coronavirus (COVID-19) - PALPC
description_narrative: The Coronavirus Pandemic (COVID-19) Control Support Project – PALPC is designed in response to the virus. It will make it possible to urgently support the health response in addition to the actions already supported by the partners at the national level and the regional support in progress with ECOWAS and taking into account Guinea Bissau’s needs in the fight against COVID-19. In addition, the Project will contribute to the capacity building of the High Commission in COVID-19 control as well as that of the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Decentralisation in order to improve their implementation and regional coordination capacity. The PALPC will be implemented through three (3) components, namely: (i) Support for community ownership and engagement; (ii) Support for health system resilience (iii), and Project management and coordination.

Le projet d'appui à la lutte contre la pandémie à Coronavirus (COVID-19) – PALPC est conçu en réponse au virus. Il permettra d'appuyer en urgence la réponse sanitaire en complément des actions déjà soutenues par les partenaires au niveau national et de l'appui régional en cours avec la CEDEAO et en tenant compte des besoins de la Guinée Bissau dans la lutte contre COVID-19. En outre, le projet contribuera au renforcement des capacités du Haut Commissariat dans le contrôle de COVID-19 ainsi que celles du Ministère de la Santé et du Ministère de la Décentralisation afin d'améliorer leur capacité de mise en œuvre et de coordination régionale. Le PALPC sera mis en œuvre à travers trois (3) composantes, à savoir : (i) l’appui à l'appropriation et à l'engagement communautaires ; (ii) l’appui à la résilience du système de santé (iii) ainsi que la Gestion et la coordination du projet.

The main objective of the project is, firstly to reduce the spread of the virus and halt the COVID-19 pandemic and, secondly, to boost the resilience of the health system and vulnerable communities. The project's specific objectives are to (i) strengthen the COVID-19 control and prevention mechanisms; (ii) support the engagement of communities and community-based COVID-19 control activities and (iii) strengthen the capacity and protection of health personnel.

L'objectif principal du projet est, premièrement, de réduire la propagation du virus et de stopper la pandémie de COVID-19 et, deuxièmement, de renforcer la résilience du système de santé et des communautés vulnérables. Les objectifs spécifiques du projet sont de (i) renforcer les mécanismes de contrôle et de prévention de COVID-19; (ii) soutenir l'engagement des communautés et les activités de contrôle de COVID-19 au niveau communautaire; et (iii) renforcer la capacité et la protection du personnel de santé.

The main beneficiary of this support is the Ministry of Health. The target population is that of Guinea Bissau, particularly vulnerable households including those headed by women, the poorest communities and those vulnerable to the COVID-19 pandemic. The number of people affected by the project is the entire Bissau Guinean population, i.e. 1,900,000, of whom 45% live in urban areas.

Le principal bénéficiaire de cette aide est le ministère de la santé. La population cible est celle de la Guinée Bissau, en particulier les ménages vulnérables, y compris ceux qui sont dirigés par des femmes, les communautés les plus pauvres et les personnes vulnérables à la pandémie de COVID-19. Le nombre de personnes touchées par le projet est la totalité de la population bissau-guinéenne, soit 1 900 000 personnes, dont 45% vivent en zone urbaine.

title_narrative: COVID-19 Response Related Supply Chain Support
description_narrative:
According to the 22 April 2020 dated 'Northwest Syria Task Force Situation Update', there have not yet been any confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Northwest Syria. The World Health Organization through the coordination of UNOCHA and the Health Cluster based out of Gaziantep have put into action the 'COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Plan’ to ensure that the humanitarian community takes the necessary steps in preparing for any COVID-19 related eventuality. Even though the limited number of laboratory tests conducted so far have not produced any COVID-19 positive results, this does not negate the fact that Northwest Syria is classified as a ‘High Risk’ area in terms of the COVID-19 epidemic, as stated by the World Health Organization. 

The global COVID-19 outbreak has led to a great imbalance of the supply and demand dynamics of acutely needed COVID-19 response related medical supplies and equipment. These supplies and equipment include Personal Protective Equipment (PPE’s) as well as ICU ventilators.

This project aims to support the COVID-19 response related supply chain of the international humanitarian community under the framework of the strategic principles put forward under the Northwest Syria COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Plan.

The project will thus procure within Turkey and deliver to World Health Organization (WHO) warehouse in Northwest Syria vital COVID-19 response related medical equipment and materials. These medical supplies will then be distributed to beneficiaries in Northwest Syria by the WHO. These medical equipment and materials will be consisting of Personal Protective Equipment as well as ventilators for medical staff working in the front lines of the COVID-19 response in Northwestern Syria.

As decided in coordination with the Health Cluster, the composition of the Personel Protective Equipment will be as follows: 1.300.000 units of 3 Layer Surgical Masks, 200.000 units of EN149 / FFP2 Masks, 100.000 units of Protective Suits, 27.000 units of Safety Goggles, 1.100.000 units of Powder-Free Nitrile Gloves. In addition 35 units of ICU ventilators will also be procured and delivered  to health facilities in need across the border in Northern Syria.
reporting_org_narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title_narrative: Cameroon - COVID-19 Crisis Response Budget Support Programme (PABRC)
Cameroun - Programme d'appui budgétaire en réponse à la COVID-19 (PABRC)
description_narrative: The proposed operation is EUR 88 million loan to the Republic of Cameroon to finance the COVID-19 Crisis Response Budget Support Programme (PABRC). The first confirmed case of COVID-19 in Cameroon dates back to 6 March 2020. By 2 June 2020, the country had more than [6 397] confirmed cases, including [3 629] recoveries and [199] deaths. The Centre (Yaoundé) and Littoral (Douala) Regions have the highest number of cases, representing about 55.8% and 32.2% of the total, respectively. The COVID-19 pandemic has revealed the structural weaknesses of the country’s health system and economy, particularly the limited human and financial resources allocated to the health sector. The programme has two components: (1) Strengthen the Response of the Health System and Mobilise Resources; and (2) Mitigate the Adverse Effects of COVID-19 on the Economy. This is a crisis response budget support as defined in the Operational Guidelines on the Programming, Design and Management of Programme-Based Support Operations – ADF/BD/IF/2014/35. The PABRC appraisal was conducted in April 2020 following a request submitted to the Bank on 9 April 2020 by the Government of Cameroon. It recommends two types of intervention: immediate actions to mitigate the impacts of the pandemic, and long-term structural actions to build the resilience of the economy to serve as a basis for economic recovery. This operation is being considered within the framework of the COVID-19 Rapid Response Facility (CRF) set up by the Bank to protect its Regional Member Countries (RMCs) and their households and private sector enterprises from the economic and social impact of the pandemic.

La présente intervention concerne un prêt d’un montant de 88 millions d’Euro à la République du Cameroun en vue du financement du Programme d’Appui budgétaire en Réponse à la Crise COVID-19 (PABRC). Au Cameroun le premier cas confirmé de la pandémie du COVID-19 date du 06 mars 2020. Au 2 juin 2020, le pays compte plus de [6 397] cas confirmés, dont [3 629] guérisons et [199] décès. Les régions du Centre (Yaoundé) et du Littoral (Douala) viennent en tête en termes de nombres des cas avec environ 55,8% et 32,2%, respectivement. La pandémie du COVID-19 a mis en évidence les faiblesses structurelles du système sanitaire du pays et de son économie, notamment les faibles ressources humaines et financières affectées à ce secteur. Le programme se décline en deux composantes : 1) Renforcement du système sanitaire de riposte et de la mobilisation des ressources ; et 2) Atténuation des effets néfastes du COVID-19 sur l’économie. Il s’agit d’un Appui Budgétaire en Réponse à une Crise tel que défini dans les directives opérationnelles sur la programmation, conception et gestion des opérations d’appui programmatique – ADF/BD/IF/2014/35. Le PABRC a été évalué au mois d’avril 2020, à la suite d’une demande du Gouvernement Camerounais adressée la Banque en date du 9 avril 2020. Il préconise deux types d’intervention, à savoir des actions d’atténuation immédiates des effets de la pandémie, et des actions structurelles de moyen long terme pour renforcer les capacités de résilience économique sur lesquelles la relance économique pourrait se baser. Cette opération est considérée dans le cadre de la Facilité de réponse rapide à la COVID-19 (CRF) que la Banque a mise en place afin de protéger ses Pays Membres Régionaux (PMR) et leurs ménages et entreprises privées de l’impact économique et social de la pandémie.

The PABRC’s goal is to check the spread of the coronavirus to save lives by mitigating its adverse socioeconomic effects on the country, particularly on households and businesses. Specifically, the programme seeks to: (i) build capacity for COVID-19 testing, management and response by providing planning and strategic tools and adequate financial resources to the health sector; (ii) stabilise household income and livelihoods to safeguard food security and promote private consumption.

Le PABRC a pour but de contenir la propagation du virus COVID-19 afin de sauver des vies en atténuant ses effets socio-économiques néfastes sur le pays, en particulier sur les ménages et entreprises. De façon spécifique, il s’agit de : (i) renforcer la capacité des tests de dépistage, prise en charge, et riposte sanitaire contre le COVID en dotant le secteur de la santé des outils de planification et de stratégie ainsi que des ressources financières adéquates ; (ii) stabiliser le revenu et les conditions de subsistance des ménages afin de préserver leur sécurité alimentaire, et soutenir par ce canal la consommation privée.

The  direct  beneficiaries  are people infected with and  affected  by  COVID-19,  households  and enterprises. The indirect beneficiaries of the programme are the Government of Cameroon, through the ministries directly involved, and Cameroonian citizens and enterprises that will be protected against the rapid and continuous spread of COVID-19.

Les  bénéficiaires  directs  du  programme  sont  les  personnes infectées,les  ménages  et  entreprises affectées par  le  COVID-19. Les  bénéficiaires indirects du programme sont l’Etat du  Cameroun,  à  travers  les 8 ministères  directement  impliqués,les  citoyens et  entreprises  camerounaises qui  seront  protégés contre une propagation rapide et continue du COVID-19.

title_narrative: Scaling up COVID-19 preparedness and response in northwest Syria
description_narrative: This project seeks financing to protect vulnerable populations in northwest Syria in response to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic through gap filling approach in areas across the pillars 2- 8 of the COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Plan: 2. Risk communication and community/public engagement 3. Surveillance, Rapid Response Teams (RRTs), and case investigation 4. Point of entry 5. Laboratory 6. Case management  7. Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) 8. Operational support and logistics. With regard to the community health workers (CHWs) program response to COVID-19 (Pillar 2), WHO will enhance the level of population awareness of the COVID-19 and enhance preparedness of population to cope with the outbreak. More specifically, WHO will support local coordination of awareness activities review community leaders to be engaged conduct capacity building program to train CHWs on COVID-19 response develop and print IEC materials including banners, billboards, posters establish a central hotline and coordination team establish sub-district reporting networks for suspected cases (funded from WHO by a different source) establish a community survey for COVID-19 assessment recruit and train CHWs in the subdistricts with gaps identify community volunteers to provide PPE for CHWs teams (funded from WHO by a different source) provide basic hygiene items to be distributed in the outreach activities. With regards to EWARN response (Pillars 3 and 5), WHO will support the partner in surveillance and laboratory activities including a Training of Trainers (ToT) for 26 District Level Officers (DLOs), trainings on surveillance and response for 200 EWARN staff, enhance existing ILI and SARI surveillance to actively search for COVID-19, enhance monitoring and reporting of disease trends using appropriate data analysis, activate RRT and case-based reporting, contact tracing, follow up and share data with WHO per IHR, activate CBS in camps, as well as activate labs in Idlib to test for ILI/SARS/COVID-19 and scale-up training for staff. With regards to the primary healthcare (PHC) response to COVID-19 (Pillars 4, 6, 7, and 8), WHO will establish 7 points of entries (POE) to screen travelers, hire staff, as well as provide PPE, vehicles for transportation, and basic IPC training. With regards to secondary and tertiary healthcare (STHC) response (Pillar 6), WHO will maintain the operations, logistics, and human resources of three hospitals with specialized intensive care unit (ICU) capacity for confirmed COVID-19 patients with severe symptoms and underlying chronic conditions. With regards to non-communicable disease management (Pillar 2), WHO will support primary healthcare centers working in non-communicable diseases and will ensure supply of NCD kits. More specifically, WHO will provide NCD messages specific for elderly and immunocompromised patients procure essential NCD drugs provide care via telemedicine for specific NCD patients with confirmed COVID-19 and those in ICUs and provide PPEs for NCD Care Teams within primary healthcare facilities. With regards to mental health program response (Pillars 2 and 6), WHO will implement mental health activities to respond to COVID-19 threat and potential outbreak in northwestern Syria. More specifically, WHO will produce IEC materials, will create and support mental health mobile clinics, create a MHPSS helpline for healthcare workers and COVID-19 patients and train  WASH staff, camp workers, community leaders, imams, youth leaders, women’s groups. The expected number of direct beneficiaries is 1,661,199.
